titleStmt.title: Albumazar. A comedy presented before the Kings Maiestie at Cambridge, the ninth of March. 1614. By the Gentlemen of Trinitie Colledge.
L'astrologo.
titleStmt.author: Tomkis, Thomas, fl. 1604-1615.
Porta, Giambattista della, 1535?-1615.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by Nicholas Okes for Walter Burre, and are to be sold at his shop, in Pauls Church-yard,

note.p: An adaptation of: Porta, Giambattista della. L'astrologo.
Reproduction of the original in the Folger Shakespeare Library.

div.p: A Comedy presented before the Kings Maiestie at Cambridge, the ninth of March, 1614.
By the Gentlemen of Trinitie Colledge.
LONDON, Printed by Nicholas Okes for Walter Burre, and are to be sold at his Shop, in Pauls Church-yard. 1615.

sp.l: THe brightnesse of so great and faire a presence,
They say, strikes cold amazement. But I feele
Contrarie effects. For from the gracious center
O'th Honorable assembly, some secret power
Inflames my courage; and, me thinkes, I am growne
Taller by th'vertue of this Audience.
And yet thus rais'd, I feare there's no retiring.
Ladies, whose beauties glad the whole Assembly,
Vpon your fauours I impose my businesse.
If't be a fault to speake this forraigne language,
(For Latine is our mother tongue) I must intreate you
To frame excuses for vs; for whose sake
Wee now speake English. All the rest, we hope,
Come purposely to grace our poore endeuours;
As we to please. In whose faire curtesie
We trust; not in our weake abilitie.

div.head: Scoen. 1.

sp.speaker: ALBVMAZAR.
sp.l: COme braue Mercurials sublim'd in cheating,
My deere companions, fellow-souldiers
I'th watchfull exercise of Theevery:
Shame not at your so large profession,
No more then I at deepe Astrologie.
For in the dayes of old, Good morrow Theife,
As welcome was receiu'd, as now Your Worship.
The Spartans held it lawfull, and th'Arabians,
So grew Arabia, Foelix; Sparta valiant.

sp.speaker: RONC.
sp.l: Read on this lecture, wise ALBVMAZAR.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Your patron Mercury in his mysterious character,
Holds all the markes of th'other wanderers,
And with his subtile influence workes in all,
Filling their stories full of robberies.
Most Trades and Callings much participate
Of yours; though smoothly gilt with th'honest title
Of Merchant, Lawyer, or such like: the learned
Onely excepted; and hee's therefore poore.

sp.speaker: HARP.
sp.l: And yet he steales one author from another.
This Poet is that Poets Plagiary,
And he a third's, till they end all in Homer.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: And Homer filtch't all from an Aegyptian Preestesse.
The world's a Theater of theft. Great rivers
Rob smaller brookes; and them the Ocean.
And in this world of ours, this Microcosme:
Guts from the stomack steale, and what they spare,
The meseraicks filch, and lay't i'th liver:
Where (least it should be found) turn'd to red Nectar,
Tis by a thousand theevish veines convey'd
And hid in flesh, nerues, bones, muscles and sinewes,
In tendons, skin and haire, so that the property
Thus altered, the theft can never be discovered.
Now all these pilfries couch't and composd in order,
Frame thee and me. Man's a quick masse of the every.

sp.speaker: RONC.
sp.l: Most Philosophicall ALBVMAZAR!

sp.speaker: HARP.
sp.l: I thought these parts had lent and borrowed mutuall.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Say they doe so: 'tis done with full intention
Nere to restore, and that's flat robbery.
Therefore go on: follow your vertu's lawes
Your card'nall vertue, great Necessity,
Wait on her close, with all occasions.
Be watchfull, haue as many eyes as heauen,
And eares as harvest: be resolu'd and impudent,
Beleeue none, trust none: for in this Citie
(As in a fought field Crowes and Carkasses)
No dwellers are but Cheaters and Cheateez.

sp.speaker: RONC.
sp.l: If all the houses in the towne were prisons,
The chambers cages, all the settles stockes,
The broad gates gallowses, and the whole people
Iustices, Iuries, Constables, Keepers and Hangmen,
I'de practise spite of all, and leaue behind mee
A fruitfull seminarie of our profession,
And call them by thy name Albumazarians.

sp.speaker: HARP.
sp.l: And I no lesse, were all the Citie theeues
As cunning as thy selfe.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Why brauely spoken,
Fitting such generous spirits: Ile make way
To your great vertue with a deepe resemblance.
Of high Astrologie. Harpax and Ronca
List to our profit: I haue new lodg'd a pray
Hard by, that taken is so fat and rich
'Twill make vs leaue off trading, and fall to purchase.

sp.speaker: HARP.
sp.l: Who is't? speak quickly.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Where good Albumazar?

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: 'Tis a rich gentleman, as old as foolish.
Th'poore remnant of whose brain that age had left him
The doating loue of a yong girle hath dried:
And which concerne's vs most, he giues firme credit
To Necromancy and Astrologie, Enter FVRBO.
Sending to me, as one that promise both.
Pandolfo is the man.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.l: What old Pandolfo?

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: The same: but stay, yon's Furbo whose smoothest brow
Shines with good newes, and's visage promises
Triumphs and Trophies to's. FVRBO playes.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: My life h'as learnt out all, I know't by's musicke;
Beare vp thy learned brow ALBVMAZAR,
Liue long of all the world admir'd,
For Art profound, and skill retir'd
To cheating by the height of starres.
Hence, Gypsies, hence, hence rogues of baser straine,
That hazard life for little gaine:
Stand off and wonder, gape and gaze a farre
At the rare skill of great ALBVMAZAR.

sp.speaker: FVRB.
sp.l: Albumazar,
Spread out thy nets at large, here's fowle abundance:
Pandolfo's ours, I vnderstand his businesse
Which I filch't closely from him, while he reveal'd
T'his man, his purposes and proiects.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Excellent!
Thankes to this instrument: for in pretence
Of teaching yong Sulpitia, th'old mans daughter,
I got accesse to th'house, and while I waited
Till she was ready, ouer-heard Pandolfo
Open his secrets to his seruant: thus 'tis.
Antonio, Pandolfo's friend, and neighbour,
Before he went to Barbary, agreed
To giue in marriage.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Furbo, this no place
Fit to consider curious points of businesse.
Come let's away, I'le hear't at large aboue.
Ronca stay you below, and entertaine him
With a lowd noise of my deepe skill in Art.
Thou know'st my Rosy modesty cannot do it.
Harpax vp you, and from my bed-chamber,
Where all things for our purposes are ready,
Second each beck, and nod, and word of ours.
You know my meaning.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.l: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: FVR.
sp.l: Yes sir.

div.stage: Furbo goes out singing, Fa la la Pandolfo's ours.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: THere's old Pandolfo, amorous as youthfull May,
And gray as Ianuary. I'le attend him here.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Cricca, I seeke thy aide, not thy crosse counsell,
I am mad in loue with Flauia, and must haue her:
Thou spend'st thy reasons to the contrary,
Like arrowes 'gainst an Anuile: I loue Flauia,
And must haue Flauia.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Sir you haue no reason,
Shee's a yong girle of sixteene, you of sixty.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: I haue no reason, nor spare roome for any,
Loue's herbinger hath chalk't vpon my heart,
And with a coale writ on my braine, for Flauia;
This house is wholy taken vp for Flauia.
Let reason get a lodging with her wit:
Vex me no more, I must haue Flauia.

sp.speaker: CRIC.
sp.l: But sir, her brother Lelio, vnder whose charge
Shee's now, after her father's death, sware boldly
Pandolfo neuer shall haue Flauia.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: His father, ere hee went to Barbary,
Promis'd her me: who be he liue or dead,
Spight of a Last of Lelio's▪ Pandolfo
Shall enioy Flauia.

sp.speaker: CRIC.
sp.l: Sir y'are too old.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: I must confesse in yeares about three score,
But in tuffe strength of body, foure and twenty,
Or two monthes lesse. Loue of yong Flauia,
More powerfull then Medea's drugges, renew's
All decay'd parts of man: my Arteryes
Blowne full with youthfull spirits, moue the bloud
To a new businesse: my withred Neru's grow plumpe
And strong, longing for action. Hence thou poore prop
Of feeblenesse and age: walke with such sires
As with cold palsies shake away their strength,
And loose their legges with curelesse gouts. Pandolfo
New moulded is for Reuels, Masks, and Musick. Cricca,
String my neglected Lute, and from my Armory
Skowre my best sword, companion of my youth,
Without which I seeme naked.

sp.speaker: CRIC.
sp.l: Your loue, sir, like strong water
To a deplor'd sicke man, quick's your feeble limbs
For a poore moment. But after one night's lodging
You'l fall so dull and cold, that Flauia
Will shrike and leape from bed as from a Sepulchre.
Shall I speake plainer, sir? Shee'l Cuckold you:
Alas shee'le Cuckold you.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: What mee? a man of knowne discretion,
Of riches, yeares, and this gray grauity?
I'le satisfy'r with gold, rich cloathes and iewels.

sp.speaker: CRIC.
sp.l: Wert not farre fitter vrge your son Eugenio
To wooe her for himselfe?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Cricca bee gone,
Touch no more there: I will and must haue Flauia.
Tell Lelio, if hee grant m'his sister Flauia,
I'le giue my daughter to him in exchange.
Be gone, and finde mee heere within this halfe houre.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: TIs well that servant's gone: I shall the easier
Wind vp his master to my purposes.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Sure this some novice of th'Artillery,
That winke's and shoots: sir, prime your peece anew
The powder's wet: tick. tock. tick. tock.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: A good ascendent blesse me: sir are you frantick?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Why franticke? are not knockes the lawfull courses
T'open doores and eares?

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Of vulgar men and houses.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Whose lodging's this? is't not th'Astrologers?

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: His lodging? no: 'tis the learn'd Phrontisterion
Of most divine Albumazar.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Good sir,
If the doore breake, a better shall redeeme it.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: How! all your land sold at a hundreth yeares purchase
Cannot repaire th'dammage of one poore rap,
To thunder at the Phrontisterion
Of great Albumazar?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Why man? what harme:

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Sir, you must know my master's heauenly braine
Pregnant with mysteries of Metaphisickes,
Growes to an Embryo of rare contemplation,
Which at full time brought forth, excel's by farre
The armed fruit of Vulcan's Midwifry
That leapt from Iupiter's mightie Cranium.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: What of all this?

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Thus one of your bold thunders may abortiue
And cause that birth miscarry, that might haue prou'd
An instrument of wonders greater and rarer
Then Apollonius the Magitian wrought.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Are you your Masters Countrey-man?

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Yes: why aske you?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Then must I get an Interpreter for your language.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: You need not; with a wind instrument my master made,
In fiue dayes you may breath ten languages
As perfect as the Divell, or himselfe.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: When may I speake with him?

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: When't please the starres.
He pul's you not a haire, nor pare's a naile,
Nor stirre's a foot without due figuring
The Horoscope: sit downe a while and't please you,
I see the heavens incline to his approach.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: What's this I pray you?

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: An engine to catch starres,
A mase t'arrest such Planets as haue lurk't
Foure thousand yeares vnder protection
Of Iupiter and Sol.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Pray you speake English.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis a perspicill, th'best vnder heauen:
With this Ile read a leafe of that small Iliade
That in a wall-nut shell was desk't, as plainly
Twelue long miles off, as you see Pauls from Highgate.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Wonderfull workman of so rare an Instrument!

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: 'Twill draw the Moone so neere that you would sweare
The bush of thornes in't prick your eyes: the Chrystall
Of a large Arch multiplie's millions,
Worke's more then by poynt blanke: and by refractions
Opticke and strange, searcheth like th'eye of truth,
All closets that haue windowes. Haue at Rome,
I see the Pope, his Card'nals and his mule,
The English Colledge and the Iesuits,
And what they write and doe.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Let me see too.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: So farre you can not: for this glasse is fram'd
For eyes of thirty: you are nigh threescore.
But for some fifty miles 'twill serue you,
With helpe of a refractiue glasse that's yonder.
For triall sir: where are you now?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: In London.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Ha you found the glasse within that chamber?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: What see you?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Wonders, wonders: I see as in a Land-shappe
An honorable throng of noble persons,
As cleare as I were vnder the same roofe.
Seemes by their gracious browes, and courteous lookes
Something they see, which if t b'indifferent
They'l fau'rably accept: if otherwise
They'l pardon, who, or what they be, I know not.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Why that's the coure! at Cambridge forty miles hence, what else?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: A Hall thrust full of bare-heads, some bald, some busht,
Some brauely branch't.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: That's th'Vniversity
Larded with Townes-men. Look you there: what now?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Who? I see Douer Peere, a man now landing
Attended by two Porters that seeme to grone
Vnder the burthen of two loades of paper.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: That's Coriatus Persicus, and's obseruations
Of Asia and Affrick.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: The price.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: I dare not sel't.
But here's another of a stranger vertue:
The great Albumazar by wondrous Art,
In imitation of this Perspicill,
Hath fram'd an Instrument that multiplies
Obiects of hearing, as this doth of seeing,
That you may know each whisper from Prester Iohn
Against the winde, as fresh as 'twere deliuered
Through a trunke, or Glosters listning wall.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: And may I see it sir? blesse me once more.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: 'Tis somthing ceremonious; but you shall try't.
Stand thus. What heare you?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Nothing

sp.speaker: RO.
sp.l: Set your hands thus
That th'vertex of the Organ may perpendicularly
Point out our Zenith. What heare you now? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: A humming noyse of laughter.

sp.speaker: RO.
sp.l: Why that's the Court
And Vniuersitie, that now are merry
With an old gentleman in a Comaedy. What now?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Celestiall musicke, but it seemes farre off.
List, list, tis neerer now.

sp.speaker: RO.
sp.l: 'Tis musick twixt the Acts. What now?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: And now?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Musicke againe, and strangely delicate.
O most Angelicall! they sing!

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: And now?
Sing sweetly, that our notes may cause
The heauenly Orbes themselues to pause:
And at our musick stand as still
As at Ioue's amorous will.
So now release them as before,
Th'haue waited long enough, no more.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: 'Tis gone, giue mee't againe.— O do not so.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: What heare you now?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: No more then a dead Oyster.
O let me see this wondrous instrument.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Sir, this is cal'd an Otacousticon.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: A Cousticon?
Why 'tis a paire of Asses eares, and large ones.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: True: for in such a forme the great Albumazar
Hath fram'd it purposely, as fit'st receiuers
Of sounds, as spectacles like eyes for sight.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: What gold will buy't?

sp.speaker: RO.
sp.l: Il'e selt you when 'tis finish't:
As yet the Epiglottis is vnperfect.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: 'Soone as you can, and here's ten crownes in earnest.
For when 'tis done, and I haue purchasd it,
I meane t'intail 't on my heires male for euer,
Spight of the ruptures of the common law.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Nay rather giu't to Flauia for her ioncture:
For shee that marries you, deserues it richly.

sp.speaker: CRIC.
sp.l: SIr, I haue spoke with Lelio, and he answer's.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Hang Lelio, and his answer's. Come hither Cricca,
Wonder for me, admire, and be astonisht,
Marvaile thy selfe to Marble at these engines,
These strange Gorgonian instruments.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: At what?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: At this rare Perspicill and Otacousticon.
For with these two Il'e heare and see all secrets,
Vndo intelligencers. Pray let my man see
What's done in Rome; his eyes are iust as your's are.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Pandolfo, are you mad? be wise and secret:
See you th'steepe danger you are tumbling in?
Know you not that these instruments haue power
T'vnlocke the hidden'st closets of whole states?
And you reueale such mysteries to a seruant?
Sir be advis'd, or else you learne no more
Of our vnknowne Philosophy.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Inough.
What newes from Lelio? shall I haue his sister?

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: He sweares and vowes he neuer will consent.
She shall not play with worne antiquities,
Nor lye with snow, and statues; and such replies
That I omit for reverence of your worship.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Not haue his sister? Cricca I will haue Flauia,
Maugre his head, by meanes of this Astrologer
I'le enioy Flauia. Are the starres yet inclin'd
To his diuine approach?

sp.speaker: RO.
sp.l: One minute brings him.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: What Strologer?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: The learned man I told thee,
Th high Almanacke of Germany, an Indian
Farre beyond Trebesond and Tripoli,
Close by the worlds end: a rare Coniurer,
And great Astrologer. His name, pray sir?

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Albumazarro Meteoroscopico.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: A name of force to hang him without tryall.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: As hee excels in Science, so in Title.
Hee tels of lost plate, horses, and strayd cattell
Directly, as hee had stolne them all himselfe.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Or hee, or some of his confederates.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: As thou respects thy life, looke to thy tongue,
Albumazar has an Otacousticon.
Bee silent, reuerent, and admire his skill,
See what a promising countenance appeares:
Stand still and wonder, wonder and stand still.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Ronca, the bunch of planets new found out
Hanging at th'end of my best Perspicill,
Send them to Galilaeo at Padua;
Let him bestow them where hee please. But th'starres
Lately discouered 'twixt the hornes of Aries,
Are as a present for Pandolfo's marriage,
And henceforth stil'd Sidera Pandolfaea.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: My marriage Cricca! hee foresee's my marriage:
O most Celestiall Albumazar!

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: And sends y'a present from the head of Aries.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: My Almanacke made for th'meridian
And height of Iapan, giu't th'East Indy company:
There may they smel the price of Cloues and Pepper,
Munkies and China-dishes fiue yeares ensuing;
And know th'successe o'th voyage of Magores.
For in the volume of the Firmament
Wee children of the starres reade things to come,
As cleerely as poore mortals stories past
In Speed or Hollingshead.

sp.speaker: RO.
sp.l: The perpetual motion
With a true larum in't to run twelue houres
'Fore Mahomets returne.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Deliuer it safe
T'a Turkie Factor, bid him with care present it
From mee to th'house of Ottoman.

sp.speaker: RO.
sp.l: I will sir.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Pray you stand here, and wonder now for mee,
Be astonish't at his Gorgon, for I cannot.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Vpon my life he proues a meere Impostor.
Peace, not a word, be silent and admire.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: As for the Issue of th'next Summers warres,
Reueal't to none, keep't to thy selfe in secret,
As touch-stone of my skill in Prophesie. Be gone.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: I goe sir.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Signior Pandolfo, I pray you pardon me,
Exoticall dispatches of great consequence
Staid me; and casting the Nativitie
O'th Cham of Tartary, and a priuate conference
With a Mercuriall intelligence.
Y'are welcome in a good houre, better minute,
Best second, happiest third, fourth, fift, and scruple.
Let the twelue houses of the Horoscope
Be lodg'd with fortitudes, and fortunates,
To make you blest in your designes Pandolfo.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Wer't not much trouble to your starry imployments,
I a poore mortall would intreat your furtherance
In a terrestriall businesse.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: My Ephemeris lies,
Or I fore-see your errant: thus 'tis, thus.
You had a neighbour cal'd Antonio,
A widdower like your selfe, whose onely daughter
Flauia, you loue, and hee as much admir'd
Your child Sulpitia. Is not this right?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Yes sir: O strange! Cricca admire in silence.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: You two decreed a counter-match betwixt you,
And purpos'd to truck daughters. Is't not so?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Iust as you say't. Cricca admire and wonder.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: This no such secret: looke to your selfe, hee'l cheate you.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Antonio after this match concluded,
Hauing great summes of gold in Barbary,
Desires of you before he consummate
The rites of matrimony, hee might goe thither,
For three months; but as now 'tis three and three
Since he imbark't, and is not yet return'd.
Now sir your businesse is to me, to know
Whether Antonio be dead or liuing.
I'le tell you instantly.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Hast thou reveal'd it?
I told it none but thee.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Why stare you?
Are you not well?

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: I wander 'twixt the Poles
And heau'nly hinges, 'mongst excentricals,
Centers, concentrickes, circles, and epicycles,
To hunt out an aspect fit for your businesse.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Meane ostentation! for shame awake your selfe.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: And since the lampe of heauen is newly entred
To Cancer, old Antonio is starke dead,
Drown'd in the sea stone dead: for radius directorius
In the sixt house; and th'waning moone by Capricorn,
Hee's dead, hee's dead.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: 'Tis an ill time to marry.
The Moone growes fork't, and walks with Capricorne.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Peace foole: these words are full of mysteries.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: What ominous face, and dismall countenance
Mark't for disasters, hated of all the heauens,
Is this that followes you?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: He is my seruant,
A plaine and honest speaker, but no harme in him.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: What see you in my face?

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Horror and darknesse, death and gallowses,
I de sweare th'wert hang'd, stood'st thou but two foote higher,
But now thy starres threaten a neerer death.
Sir, send to toale his knell.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: What is he dead?

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: He shall be by the dint of many stabs:
Onely I spy a little hope of scaping
Thorough the clouds, and foule aspects of death,

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Sir, pray giue no credit to this cheater,
Or with his words of Art hee'le make you dote
As much on his fain'd skill, as on faire Flauia.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.l: STay Villaine, stay, though safety 't selfe defends thee
Thou diest.

sp.speaker: FVR.
sp.l: Come do thy worst, thrust sure, or die.

sp.speaker: CRIC.
sp.l: For heau'n sake Gentlemen stay your hands, help, helpe.
Help Albumazar.

sp.speaker: HARP.
sp.l: Thus to the hinderer
Of my reuenge.

sp.speaker: CRIC.
sp.l: Saue me Albumazar.

sp.speaker: FVRB.
sp.l: And thus, and thus, and thus.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Maister I die, I dye.

sp.speaker: HARP.
sp.l: Fliest thou base coward? 'tis not thy heeles can saue thee.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Ooh!

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: What ailes thee Cricca?

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: I am dead, I am dead,
Trouble your selfe no more.

sp.speaker: PA.
sp.l: What dead & speakst?

sp.speaker: CRIC.
sp.l: Onely there's left a little breath to tell you.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Why, where art hurt?

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Stab'd with a thousand daggers,
My heart, my lights, my liuer, and my skin,
Pearst like a siue.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Here's not a wound, stand vp,
'Tis but thy feare.

sp.speaker: CRIC.
sp.l: 'Tis but one wound all ouer.
Softly, ô softly: y'haue lost the truest seruant; Farewell I die.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Liue by my curtesie, stand vp and breath.
The dangerous and malignant influence is past:
But thank my charity that put by the blowes,
The least of which threatned a dozen graues.
Now learne to scoffe diuine Astrologie,
And slight her seruants.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: A Chirurgion, good sir, a Surgeon.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Stand vp man, th'hast no harme, my life for thine.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Th'art well, th'art well.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Now I perceiue I am:
I pray you pardon me Diuine Astrologer.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: I do, but hence-forth laugh at Astrologie
And call her seruants Cheaters.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Now to our businesse: on good Albumazar.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Now since the Moone passeth from Capricorne,
Through Aquarius to the watry Signe of Pisces,
Antonio's drown'd, and is deuour'd by fishes.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Is't certaine?

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Certaine.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Then let my earnestnes
Intreate your skill a fauour.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: It shall, but first
I'le tell you what you meane to aske me.

sp.speaker: PA.
sp.l: Strange!

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Antonio dead that promis'd you his daughter,
Your businesse is t'entreate mee raise his ghost,
And force it stay at home til't haue perform'd
The promise past, and so returne to rest.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: That, that, y'haue hit it most diuine Albumazar.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: 'Tis a hard thing; for de preuatione ad habitum non datur regressus.
O what a businesse what a maister peece
'Tis to raise vp his Ghost, whose bodie's eaten
By fish. This work desires a Planetary intelligence
Of Iupiter and Sol, and these great Spirits,
Are proud, phantasticall: It ask's much charges,
T'entice them from the guiding of their Spheares
To waite on mortals.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: So I may haue my purpose, spare for no cost.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Sir, spare your purse, wee'l do't an easier way.
The worke shall cost you nothing.
We haue an Art is cal'd Prastigiatory,
That deales with spirits, and intelligences
Of meaner office and condition,
Whose seruice craue's small charges: with one of these
I'le change some seruant, or good friend of yours
To th'perfect shape of this Antonio:
So like in face, behauiour, speech, and action,
That all the Towne shall sweare Antonio liues.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Most Necromanticall Astrologer,
Do this, and take mee for your seruant euer.
And for your paines, after the transformation
This chaine is your's, it cost two hundred pound
Beside the iewell.

sp.speaker: AL.
sp.l: After the work is finish't, then— how now?
What lines are these that looke sanguineous?
As if the Starres coniur'd to do you mischiefe?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: How? meane you mee?

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: They'r dusky marks of Saturne.
It seemes some stone shall fall vpon your head,
Threatning a fracture of the Pericrantum.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Cricca come hither, fetch me my staffe againe,
Three-score and ten's return'd: A generall Palsie
Shakes out the loue of Flauia with a feare.
Is there no remedy?

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Nothing but patience.
The Planet threatens so, whose prey you are.
The Starres and Planets daily warre together.
For should they stand at truce but one halfe houre
This wondrous Machin of the world would ruin.
Who can withstand their powrefull influence?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: You with your wisedome, good Albumazar.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Indeed th'Aegyptian Ptolamee the wise,
Pronounst it as an Oracle of truth; Sapiens dominabitur astris.
Who's aboue there? Ronca bring downe the cap
Made in the point of Mercury being ascendent:
Here put it on, and in your hand this Image,
Fram'd on a Tuesday when the fierce God of warre
Mounted th'horizon in the signe of Aries.
With these walke as vnwounded as Achilles,
Dip't by his mother Thetis.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: You bind mee to your seruice.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Next get the man you purpose to transforme
And meete mee heere.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: I will not faile to finde you.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Meane while with Sciofericall instrument,
By way of Azimuth and Almicantarath
I'le seeke some happy point in heauen for you.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: I rest your seruant, sir.

sp.speaker: AL.
sp.l: Let all the Starres
Guide you with most propitious influence.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: HEere's a strange man indeed, of skill profound:
How right hee knew my businesse, 'fore hee saw mee,
And how thou skoft's him when we talk't in priuate.
Tis a braue instrument his Otacousticon.

sp.speaker: CRIC.
sp.l: In earnest sir I tooke him for a Cheater;
As many, vnder name of cunning men
With promise of Astrology, much abuse
The gaping vulgar, wronging that sacred skill,
That in the Starres reades all our actions.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Is there no arches o're our heads, looke Cricca.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: None but the Arch of heauen, that cannot fall.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Is not that made of Marble? I haue read
A stone drop't from the Moone: And much I feare
The fit should take her now, and void an other.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Feare nothing sir, this charm'd Mercuriall cap
Shields from the fall of Mountaines: 'tis not a stone
Can check his Art, walke boldly.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: I do, let's in.

sp.speaker: TRINCALA.
sp.p: HEE that saith I am not in loue, hee lies De cap à pe; For I am idle, choicely neate in my cloathes, valiant, and extreme witty: My meditations are loded with metaphors, and my songs sonnets: Not a one shakes his taile, but I sigh out a passion: thus do I to my Mistresse; but alas I kisse the dogge, and shee kicks mee. I neuer see a yong wanton Filly, but, say I, there goe's Armellina; nor a lusty strong Asse, but I remember my selfe, and sit downe to consider what a goodly race of Mules would inherit, if she were willing: onely I want vtterance, and that's a maine marke of loue too.

sp.speaker: ARM.
sp.p: Trincalo. Trincalo.

sp.speaker: TRINC.
sp.p:
O 'tis Armellina: now if she have the wit to beginne, as I meane shee should, then will I confound her with complements
drawne from the Plaies I see at the Fortune, and Red Bull, where I learne all the words I speake and vnderstand not.

sp.speaker: ARM.
sp.p: Trincalo, what price beare's wheate, and Saffron, that your band's so stiffe and yellow? not a word? why Trincalo! what businesse in Towne? how do's all at Totnam? growne mute? What do you bring from the Country?

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.p: There 'tis. Now are my floud-gates drawne, and I'le surround her. What haue I brought sweete bit of beauty? a hundreth thousand salutations o'th' elder house to your most illustrious Honour and Worship.

sp.speaker: ARM.
sp.p: To me these Titles? is your basket full of nothing else?

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.p: Full of the fruites of loue, most resplendent Lady; a present to your worthines from your worship's poore vassaile Trincalo.

sp.speaker: ARM.
sp.p: My life on't, hee scrap't these complements from his Cart, the last Load hee carried for the Progresse. What ha you read that make you grow so eloquent?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.p: Sweete Madame, I read nothing but the lines of your Ladiships countenance, and desire onely to kisse the skirts of your garment, if you vouchsafe mee not the happinesse of your white hands.

sp.speaker: ARM.
sp.p: Come, giue's your basket and take it.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.p: O sweete! now will I neuer wash my mouth after, nor breath but at my nosthrils, least I loose the tast of her fingers. Armellina, I must tell you a secret if you'le make much on't.

sp.speaker: ARM.
sp.p: As it deseru's: what is't?

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.p: I loue you, deere morsell of modesty, I loue: and so truely, that I'le make you Mistres of my thoughts, Lady of my reuenewes, and commit all my moueables into your hands, that is, I giue you an earnest kisse in the high way of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: ARM.
sp.p: Is this the end of all this businesse?

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.p: This is the end of all businesse, most beautifull, and most worthy to be most beautifull Lady.

sp.speaker: ARM.
sp.p: Hence foole, hence.

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.p:
Why now she knowes my meaning, let it worke: Shee put vp the fruite in her lappe, and threw away the basket: 'Tis a plaine signe, shee abhorr's the words, and embraces the meaning: O lippes, no lippes, but leaues besmear'd with mel-dew!
ô dew no dew, but drops of Hony combs! ô combs no combs, but fountaines full of teares! ô teares no teares, but—

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: CRicca denie's mee; no perswasions,
Proffers, rewards, can worke him to transforme.
Yonder's my Country Farmer Trincalo.
Neuer in sitter time good Trincalo.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Like a leane horse t'a fresh and lusty Pasture.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: What rent do'st pay me for thy Farme at Totnam?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Ten pound; and find't too deere a peny-worth.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: My hand here: take it rent-free for three liues,
To serue me in a businesse I'le employ thee.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Serue you? I'le serue, reserue, conserue, preserue,
Deserue you for th'one halfe: ô Armellina,
A Ioincture, hai a Ioincture! what's your employment?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Here's an Astrologer has a wondrous secret
To transforme men to other shapes, and persons.

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.l: How? transforme things to men? I'le bring nine Taylors
Refus'd last Muster, shall giue fiue Markes a peece
To shape three men of seruice out of all,
And grant him th'remnant shreds aboue the bargaine.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Now if thou'lt let him change thee, take this Lease;
Drawne ready; put what liues thou pleasest.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Stay, Sir.
Say I am transform'd; who shall enioy the Lease?
I? or the person I must turne to.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Thou,
Thou. The resemblance last's but one whole day:
Then home true Farmer, as thou wer't before.

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.l: Where shall poore Trincalo be? how's this? transform'd?
Transmuted? how? not I; I loue my selfe
Better then so: there's your Lease. I'de not venter
For th'whole Fee-simple.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Tell me the difference
Betwixt a foole and wise man.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: 'Faith as much
As twixt your Worship and my selfe.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: A wise man
Accept's all faire occasions of aduancement,
Flye's no commodity for feares of danger,
Venter's and gaines, liues easily, drinkes good wine,
Fare's neatly, 's richly cloath'd, in worthiest company;
While your poore foole and Clowne, for feare of peril,
Sweat's hourely for a dry browne crust to bed-ward,
And wake's all night for want of moysture.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Well, sir,
I'de rather starue in this my loued Image,
Then hazard thus my life, for others lookes.
Change is a kind of death, I dare not try it.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: 'Tis not so dangerous as thou tak'st it; wee'l only
Alter thy count'nance for a day. Imagine
Thy face mask't onely: or that thou dream'st all night
Thou wer't apparell'd in Antonio's forme,
And waking find'st thy selfe true Trincalo.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: T'antonio's forme? was not Antonio a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Yes, and my neighbour, that's his house.

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.l: O ho!
Now do I smell th'Astrologer's tricke: hee'l steepe mee
In souldiers bloud; or boyle me in a Chaldron
Of Barbarous Law French: Or annoint me ouer
With supple oyle of great men's seruices.
For these three meanes raise Yeomen to the Gentry.
Pardon me sir: I hate these medcines. Fy!
All my posterity will smell and tast on't
'Long as the house of Trincalo endures.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Ther's no such busines, thou shall't only seeme so
And thus deceiue Antonio's family.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Are you assur'd? 'twould grieue me to be bray'd
In a huge Mortar, wrought to paste, and moulded
To this Antonio's mould: Grant I be turn'd: what then?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Enter his house, be reuerenc'd by his seruants,
And giue his daughter Flauia to me in marriage.
The circumstances I'le instruct thee after.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Pray giue me leaue: this side saies do't, this do not.
Before I leaue you Tom Trincalo take my counsell.
Thy Mistresse Armellina is Antonios Mayde,
And thou in his shape maist possesse her. Turne.
But if I be Antonio, then Antonio
Enioyes that happinesse, not Trincalo.
A pretty trick to make my selfe a Cuckold.
No, no; there, take your Lease. I'le hang first. Soft,
Be not so cholerick Thomas: If I become Antonio,
Then all his riches follow. This faire occasion
Once vanish't, hope not the like; of a starke Clowne
I shall appeare speck and span Gentleman.
A pox of Ploughes, and Carts, and Whips, and Horses.
Then Armellina shall be giuen to Trincalo,
Three hundred Crownes her portion: wee'l get a boy
And call him Transformation Trincalo.
I'le doo't sir.

sp.speaker: PA.
sp.l: Art resolu'd?

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.l: Resolu'd? 'tis done:
With this condition: after I haue giv'n your Worship
My daughter Flauia, you shall then moue my Worship
And much entreate me, to bestow my Maide
Vpon my selfe, I should say Trincalo.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Content, and for thy sake will make her portion
Two hundred Crownes.

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.l: Now are you much deceiu'd
I neuer meant it.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: I did but iest.
And yet my hand, I'le do't. For I am mutable
And therefore apt to change. Come, come sir, quickly,
Let's to th'Astrologer, and there transforme,
Reforme, conforme, deforme me at your pleasure.
I loath this Country countnance; dispatch: my skin
Itch'es like Snakes in Aprill, to be strip't off.
, ô quickly, as you loue Flauia, quickly.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: SIgnior Pandolfo, y'arriue in happiest houre.
If the seuen Planets were your neerest kindred,
And all the Constellations your Allies:
Were the twelue houses, and the Innes o'th' Zodiack
Your owne fee-simple; they could nere haue chosen
A fitter place to fauour your designes.
For the great Luminaries looke from Hilech,
And midst of heauen in angles, coniunctions,
And fortunate aspects of Trine and Sextile,
Ready to powre propitious influences.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Thank's to your power and curt'sie that so plac'd them.
This is the man that's ready for the businesse.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Of a most happy count'nance, and timber fit
To square to th'gentry: his lookes as apt for changing,
As he were cou'red with Camaelions skins.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Except my hands; and 'twill be troublesome
To fit these fingers to Antonio's gloues.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Pray let's about the worke as soone as may be.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: First choose a large low roome, whose doore's full East,
Or neere inclining: for th'Orientall quarter's
Most bountifull of fauours.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: I haue a parler
Of a great square and height, as you desire it.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Southward must looke a wide and spatious window:
For howsoeuer Omar, Alchabitius,
Hali, Abenezra, seeme something to dissent;
Yet Zoroastres, sonne of Oromasus,
Hiarcha, Brachman, Thespion Gymnesophist,
Gebir, and Budda Babylonicus,
With all the subtile Cabalists and Chaldees,
Sweare the best influence: for our metamorphosis
Stoopes from the South, or as some say, South-east.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: This roome's as fit as you had made't of purpose.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Now doe I feele the calfe of my right legge
Tingle, and dwindle to th'smalnesse of a bed-staffe.
Such a speech more turns my high shooes strait boots.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Nere were those Authors cited to better purpose.
For through that window all Pandolfo's treasures
Must take their flight and fall vpon my shoulders.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Now if this light meridionall had a large casement
That ouer-look't some vnfrequented alley,
'Twere much more proper: for th'Intelligences
Are nice and coy, scorning to mixe their essence
With throng'd disturbance of crosse multitudes.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Spoken by Art. Albumazar: a provident setter:
For so shall we receiue what thou hand'st out
Free from discovery. But in my conscience
All windowes poynt full South for such a businesse.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Go to my house, satisfie your curious choyce,
But credit me, this parler's fit, it neighbours
To a blinde Alley, that in busiest tearme-time
Feeles not the footing of one passenger.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Now then declining from Theourgia,
Artenosoria, Pharmacia, reiecting
Necro-puro-geo-hydro-cheiro-coscinomancy,
With other vaine and superstitious sciences,
Wee'l ancor at the Art Prestigiatorie,
That represents one figure for another,
With smooth deceit abusing th'eyes of mortals.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: O my right arme! 'tis alter'd, and me thinkes
Longs for a sword: these words haue slaine a Plow-man.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: And since the Moone's the onely Planet changing:
For from the Neomenia in seuen dayes
To the Dicotima, in seven more to th'Pauselinum,
And in as much from Plenilunium
Thorow Dicotima to Neomenia,
'Tis she must helpe vs in this operation.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: What townes are these? the strangenesse of these names,
Hath scal'd the marks of many a painfull haruest,
And made my new-pil'd fingers itch for dice.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Deeply considred wondrous Albumazar:
O let me kisse those lips that flow with science.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: For by her various lookes she intimates
To vnderstanding soules, that onely she
Hath power t'effect a true formation.
Cause then your parler to be swept carefully,
Wash't, rub'd, perfum'd, hang'd round from toppe to bottome
With pure white lunary Tapistry, or needle-worke;
But if 'twere cloath of siluer, 'twere much better.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Good, good! a rich beginning: good! what's next?

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Spread all the floore with finest Holland sheets,
And ouer them faire damaske Table-cloathes,
Aboue all these draw me chast virgins aprons:
The roome, the worke, and workman must be pure.

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.l: With virgins aprons? th'whole compasse of this Citie
Can not affoord a dozen.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: So, there's shirts
And bands to furnish all on's for a twelue-month.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: An Altar in the midst, loaded with plate
Of siluer, Basens, Yewres, Cups, Candlestickes,
Flaggons and Beakers, Salts, Chargers, Casting-bottles.
'Twere not amisse to mixe some Bowles of gold,
So they be massie; the better to resemble
The louely brother-hood of Sol and Luna.
Also some Diamonds for Iupiter.
For by the whitenesse and bright sparkling lustres
We allure th'Intelligences to descend.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Furbo and I are those Intelligences
That must attend vpon the Magistery.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Now for the ceremonious sacrifice,
Prouide such creatures as the Moone delights in,
Two sucking lambes, white as the Alpine snow:
Yet if they haue a mole or two, 'twill passe.
The Moone her sefe wants not her spots.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Were they hell-black, wee'd make a shift to eate them.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: White Capons, Pheasants, Pigions: one little Blacke-bird
Would staine and spoyle the worke. Get seuerall Wines
To quench the holy embers: Rhenish, Greeke wine,
White Muskadell, Sheery, and rich Canarie,
So't be not growne too yellow: for the quicker,
Brisker, and older, the better for these ceremonies.
The more abundance, sooner shall wee finish.
For 'tis our rule in such like businesses,
Who spares most, spends most: either this day must doo't,
Or th'reuolution of fiue hundred yeares
Cannot: so fit are all the heauens to helpe vs.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: A thousand thankes, thou'lt make a compleate cheate.
Thus loaded with this treasure, cheer'd with wine,
Strengthned with meate: wee'l carry thee in triumph,
As the great Generall of our atchieuement.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Sir, for rich plate and iewels I haue store,
But know not how to furnish you with hangings.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Cannot you borrow from the shops? foure houres
Shall render all as faire as you receiu'd it.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: That can I easily doe.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: And heare you sir:
If you chance meet with boxes of white Comfites,
Marchpane, dry sucket, Macarouns and diet-bread,
'Twill helpe on well.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: To furnish out our banquet.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: I had cleane forgot, we must haue Amber Greece,
The grayest can be found, some dozen ounces,
I'le vse but halfe a dram: but 'tis our fashion
T'offer a little from a greater lumpe.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: All shall be done with expedition.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: And when your man's transform'd, the chaine you promis'd.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: My hand: my deedes shall wait vpon my promise.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Lead then with happy foote to view the chamber.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: I goe sir. Trincalo attend vs here,
And not a word on perill of thy life.

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.l: Sir, if they kill me Il'e not stirre a foot,
And if my tongue's puld out, not speake a word.

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.l: O what a businesse 'tis to be transform'd!
My master talkes of foure and twenty houres,
But if I mue these Flagges of Yeomanry,
Guild in the seare, and shine in bloome of gentry,
'Tis not their Strology, nor Sacrifice,
Shall force mee cast that coat. I'le neuer part with't
Till I be Shriefe of th'Countie, and in commission
Of Peace and Quorum. Then will I get m'a Clarke,
A practiz'd fellow, wiser then my Worship.
And dominere amongst my fearefull neighbours,
And feast them bountifully with their owne bribes.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Trincalo!

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Weare a gold chaine at euery quarter Sessions,
Looke big, and graue, and speak not one wise word.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Trincalo!

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Examine wenches got with child, and curiously
Search all the circumstances: haue blank Mittimusses
Printed in readinesse; breathe nought but Sirra,
Rogue, ha? how? hum? Constable looke to your charge.
Then vouch a Statute and a Latine Sentence,
Wide from the matter.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Trincalo.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: License all Alehouses,
Match my sonne Transformation t'a knights daughter,
And buy a bouncing Pedigree of a welsh Heralt: and then—

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: What in such serious meditations?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Faith no; but building Castles in the aire.
While th'weather's fit: O Cricca, such a businesse!

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Nay soft, th'are secrets of my master.
Lock't in my breast: he has the key at's purse-strings.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: My masters secret? keep it good Farmer, keep it,
I would not lend an eare to't if thou'dst hire me. Fare-well.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: O how it boyles and swels: if I keep't longer,
'Twill grow t'impostume in my breast, and choake me, Cricca.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Adieu good Trincalo, the secrets of our betters
Are dangerous, I dare not know't.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: But hear'st thou,
Say I should tell, canst keep't as close as I doe?

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Yes: but I had rather want it. Adieu.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Albumazar.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Albumazar.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Pre'thee.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Albumazar
Th'Astrologer hath vnder-tooke to change me
T'antonio's shape: this done, must I giue Flauia
To my old master, and his maid to Trincalo.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: But where's Pandolfo and Albumazar?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Gone newly home to choose a chamber fitting
For transmutation: So now my heart's at ease.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: I feare the skill and cunning of Albumazar
With his blacke Art, by whom Pandolfo seekes
To compasse Flauia, spight of her brother Lelio,
And his own sonne Eugenio that loues her deerely.
I'le loose no time, but find them and reveale
The plot and worke to crosse this accident.
But Trincalo, art thou so rash and ventrous
To be transform'd with hazard of thy life?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: What care I for a life, that haue a lease
For three? But I am certaine there's no danger in't.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: No danger? cut thy finger and that paines thee;
Then what wil't do to shred and mince thy carkasse,
Bury't in horse-dung, mould it new, and turne it
t'antonio? and when th'art chang'd, if Lelio
Smell out your plot, what worlds of punishment
Thou must endure, poore Trincalo! The desire
Of gaines abuses thee: be not transform'd.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Cricca thou vnderstandst not: for Antonio
Whom I resemble, suffers all: not I.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Yonder they come, I'le hence and hast to Lelio.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: THe chamber's fit: prouide the plate and hangings,
And other necessaries: giue strict order
The roome be cleans'd, perfum'd, and hang'd, meane while,
With Astralobe, and Meteoroscope,
Il'e finde the Cuspe and Alfriduria,
And know what Planet is in Cazimi.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: All shall be ready sir, as you command it.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Doctor Albumazar, I haue a veine of drinking,
And artery of lechery, runs through my body:
Pray when you turne me gentleman, preserue
Those two, if t may be done with reputation.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Feare not, I'le only call the first, good fellowship,
And th'other, ciuill recreation.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: And when you come to th'hart, spoyle not the loue of Armellina.
And in my braine leaue as much discretion
As may spye falshood in a Tauerne reckoning;
And let me alone for bounty to winke and pay't.
And if you change me perfectly,
I'le bring y'a dozen knights for customers.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: I warrant thee: sir are you well instructed
In all these necessaries?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Th'are in my table-booke.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Forget not cloathes for th'new transform'd, and roabes
For me to sacrifice: you know the fashion.
I'le rather change fiue, then apparrell one:
For men haue liuing soules, cloathes are vnanimate.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Here take this ring, deliuer it to my brother,
An officer in the Wardrobe, hee'l furnish you
With robes and cloathes of any stuffe, or fashion.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Almuten Alchochoden of the starres attend you.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: I kisse your hands diuine Astrologer.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: VP quickly Trincalo to my child Sulpitia,
Bid her lay out my fairest Damaske Table-cloathes.
The fairest Holland sheetes, all th'siluer plate,
Two gossips cups of gold: my greatest Diamonds:
Make hast.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: As fast as Alchochoden and Almuten
Can carry me: for sure these two are Divels.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: This is that blessed day I so much long'd for:
Foure houres attendance till my man be chang'd,
Fast lockes me in the louely armes of Flauia. Away Trincalo.
How slow the day slides on! When we desire
Times hast, it seemes to loose a match with Lobsters,
And when we wish him stay, he imp's his wings
With feathers plum'd with thought. Why Trincalo!

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Come let's away for cloath of siluer,
Wine and materials for the Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: Eugenio, these are wonders past beliefe.
Is your old father of so poore a iudgement
To thinke it in the power of man to turne
One person to another?

sp.speaker: EV.
sp.l: Lelio, his desire
T'inioy your sister Flauia, begets hope,
Which like a waking dreame, makes false apparence
Liuely as truth it selfe.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: But who's the man
That workes these miracles?

sp.speaker: EVG.
sp.l: An Astrologer.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: How deales Astrologie with transmutation?

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Vnder the vaile and colour of Astrologie,
He clouds his hellish skill in Necromancie.
Beleeue it, by some Art, or false imposture,
Hee'l much disturbe your loue, and yours, Eugenio.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: Eugenio, 'tis high time for vs t'awake.
And as you loue our Flauia, and I
Your sister faire Sulpitia; let's doe something
Worthy their beauties. Who falles into a sea,
Swolne bigge with tempest, but he boldly beates
The waues with armes and legges, to saue his life?
So let vs striue 'gainst troublous stormes of loue,
With our best power, least after we ascribe
The losse to our dull negligence, not Fortune.

sp.speaker: EV.
sp.l: Lelio, had I no interest in your sister,
The holy league of friendship should command me,
Besides the seconding Sulpitia's loue,
Who to your noblenesse commends her life.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: She cannot out-loue me, nor you out-friend me,
For th'sacred name whereof, I haue reiected
Your fathers offers, importunities,
Letters, Conditions, Seruants, Friends, and lastly
His tender of Sulpitia in exchange
For Flauia. But though I loue your sister
Like mine owne soule; yet did the lawes of friendship
Master that strong affection; and denied him.

sp.speaker: EVG.
sp.l: Thankes euer, and as long shall my best seruice
Waite on your will. Cricca our hope's in thee,
Thou must instruct vs:

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: You must trust in Fortune
That make's or marr's the wisest purposes.

sp.speaker: LEL.
sp.l: What sai'st? What thinkst?

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Here's no great need of thinking
Not speech; the oile of scorpions cure's their poison.
The thing it selfe that's bent to hurt and hinder you
Offer's a remedie: 'tis no sooner knowne
But th'worst on't is preuented.

sp.speaker: EVG.
sp.l: How good Cricca?

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Soone as you see this false Antonio
Come neere your dores with speeches made of purpose,
Full of humility and compassion:
With long narrations how he scap't from ship-wrack
And other fain'd inuentions of his dangers:
Bid him be gone; and if he presse to enter,
Feare not the reuerence of your father's lookes,
Cudgell him thence.

sp.speaker: LEL.
sp.l: But wer't not better Cricca
Keepe him fast lock't, till his owne shape returne,
And so by open course of Law correct him?

sp.speaker: CRIC.
sp.l: No. For my maister would conceiue that counsell
Sprung from my braines: and so should I repent it.
Aduise no more, but home and charge your people,
That if Antonio come, they driue him thence
With threatning words, and blowes if need be.

sp.speaker: LEL.
sp.l: 'Tis done.
I kisse your hands Eugenio.

sp.speaker: EVG.
sp.l: Your seruant, sir.

sp.speaker: EVG.
sp.l: CRicca commend my seruice to my Mistresse.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Commend it t'her your selfe. Mark't you not, while
We talk't, how through the window she attended,
And fed her eyes on you? there shee's.

sp.speaker: EVG.
sp.l: 'Tis true.
And as from nights of Stormes the glorious Sunne
Breake's from the East, and chaseth thence the Clouds
That choak't the Aire with horror; so her beauty
Dispels sad darknesse from my troubled thoughts,
And cleare's my heart.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Life of my soule well met.

sp.speaker: EVG.
sp.l: How is't my deerest Flauia?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Eugenio,
As best becomes a woman, most vnfortunate.
That hauing lou'd so long, and beene perswaded
Her chaste affection was by your's requited,
Haue by delayes beene famish'd. Had I conceal'd
Those flames your vertue kindled, then y'had sued,
Intreated, sworne, and vow'd, and long e're this
Wrought all meanes possible to effect our marriage.
But now.

sp.speaker: EVG.
sp.l: Sweet soule despaire not, weep not thus,
Vnlesse you wish my heart should life-bloud drop,
Fast as your eyes do teares. What is't you feare?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: First that you loue me not.

sp.speaker: EVG.
sp.l: Not loue my Flauia?
Wrong not your iudgement: rip vp this amorous brest
And in that Temple see a heart that burne's
I'th' vestall sacrifice of chastest loue,
Before your beauties Deity.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: If so,
Whence growes this coldnesse in soliciting
My brother to the match?

sp.speaker: EVG.
sp.l: Consider sweetest,
I haue a father riuall in my loue;
And though no duty, reuerence, nor respect
Haue power to change my thoughts: yet 'tis not comly
With open violence to withstand his will;
But by faire courses try to diuert his minde
From disproportioned affections.
And if I cannot, then nor feare of anger,
Nor life, nor lands, shall crosse our purposes.
Comfort your selfe sweet Flauia: for your brother
Second's our hopes with his best seruices.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: But other feares oppresse mee: mee thinkes I see
Antonio my old father, new return'd,
Whom all intelligence gaue drown'd this three monthes,
Enforcing mee to marry th'foole Pandolfo,
Thus to obtaine Sulpitia for himselfe.
And so last night I dream'd, and euer since
Haue bene so scar'd, that if you hast not
Expect my death.

sp.speaker: EVG
sp.l: Dreames flow from thoughts of things we most desire,
Or feare, and seldome proue true Prophets, would they did.
Then were I now in full possession
Of my best Flauia: as I hope I shall be.

sp.speaker: CRIC.
sp.l: Sir, pray take your leaue, this to no end,
'T will but encrease your griefe and hers.

sp.speaker: EVG.
sp.l: Farewell
Sweete Flauia, rest contented with assurance
Of my best loue and seruice.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Farewell Eugenio.

sp.speaker: SVL.
sp.p: FLauia I kisse your hands.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Sulpitia I pray you pardon mee, I saw you not.

sp.speaker: SV.
sp.p: I faith you haue some fix't thoughts draw your eyes inward when you see not your friends before you.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: True, and I thinke the same that trouble you.

sp.speaker: SV.
sp.p: Then 'tis the loue of a yong Gentleman, and bitter hatred of an old Dotard.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: 'Tis so, witnesse your brother Eugenio, and the rotten Karcase of Pandolfo. Had I a hundred hearts, I should want roome to entertaine his loue, and the other's hate.

sp.speaker: SV.
sp.p: I could say as much, were't not sinne to slander the dead. Miserable wenches, how haue we offended our fathers, that they should make vs the price of their dotage, the medcine of their griefes, that haue more need of Physick our selues? I must bee frost-bitten with the cold of your Dads winter, that mine may thaw his old ice with the Spring of your sixteene. I thank my dead mother that left mee a womans will in her last Testament: That's all the weapons we poore girles can vse, and with that will I fight 'gainst father, friends, and kindred, and either enioy Lelio, or dye in the field in's quarrell.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Sulpitia, you are happy that can withstand your fortune with so merry a resolution.

sp.speaker: SV.
sp.p: Why? should I twine mine armes to cables, and sigh my soule to Aire? Sit vp all night like a Watching Candle, and distill my braines through my eye-lids? your brother loues mee, and I loue your brother; and where these two consent, I would faine see a third could hinder vs.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Alas, our Sex is most wretched, nurst vp from infancie in continuall slauerie. No sooner able to pray for our selues, but they brayle and hudde vs so with sowre awe of parents, that wee dare not offer to bate at our owne desires. And whereas it becomes men to vent their amorous passions at their pleasure; wee poore soules must rake vp our affections in the ashes of a burnt heart, not daring to sigh, without excuse of the Spleene, or fit of the mother.

sp.speaker: SVL.
sp.p: I plainely will professe my loue of Lelio, 'tis honest, chast, and staines not modesty. Shall I be married to Antonio, that hath beene a soust Sea-fish, this three months? and if hee bee aliue comes home with as many impaires, as a Hunting Gelding fal'n Pack-horse. No, no, I'le see him freeze to Christall first. In other things, good father, I am your most obedient daughter, but in this a pure woman. 'Tis your part to offer, mine to refuse if I like not. Lelio's a hansome Gentleman, yong, fresh, rich, and well-fashioned, and him will Sulpitia haue, or dye a maide: And ifaith the temper of my bloud tel's me I was neuer borne to so cold a misfortune. Fye Flauia, fye wench, no more with teares and sighs, cheere vp, Eugenio to my knowledge loues you, and you shall haue him: I say you shall haue him.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: I doubt not of his loue, but know no meanes, how hee dares worke against so great a Riuall: your father in a spleene may disinherite him.

sp.speaker: SVL.
sp.p: And giue't to whom? has none but him and mee: What though he dote a while vpon your beauty; hee will not proue vnnaturall to his sonne. Goe to your chamber: my Genius whispers in my eare, and sweares this night we shall enioy our loues, and with that hope fare-well.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Fare-well Sulpitia.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: WHile the Astrologer hew's out Trincalo,
Squaring and framing him t'antonio,
Cricca I'le make thee partner of a thought
That some thing troubles me.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Say, sir, what ist?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: I haue no heart to giue Albumazar
The chaine I promist him.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Deliuer it me
And I'le present it to him in your name.

sp.speaker: PA.
sp.l: 'Thas bene an Aireloome to our house foure hundreth yeares,
And should I leaue it now, I feare good fortune
Would slye from vs, and follow it.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Then giue him
The price in gold.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: It comes to a hundred pounds.
And how would that well husbanded grow in time?
I was a foole to promise, I confesse it,
I was too hote and forward in the businesse.

sp.speaker: CRIC.
sp.l: Indeed I wondred that your wary thriftinesse
Not wont to drop one peny in a quarter
Idly, would part with such a summe so easily.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: My couetous thrift aimes at no other marke
Then in fit time and place to shew my bounty.
Who giues continually, may want at length
Wherewith to feed his liberality.
But for the loue of my deere Flauia
I would not spare my life, much lesse my treasure.
Yet if with honour I can win her cheaper,
Why should I cast away so great summe?

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: True: I haue a trick now hatching in my braine
How you may hansomely preserue your credit,
And saue the chaine.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: I would gladly do it,
But feare hee vnderstands vs what wee say.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: What can you loose to try't, if it take
There's so much sau'd, if otherwise, nothing lost.

sp.speaker: PA.
sp.l: What is't good Cricca?

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Soone as Albumazar come's, loded with newes
Of th'transmutation of your seruant Trincalo,
I'le entertaine him here: meane while steale you
Closely into the roome, and quickly hide
Some speciall peece of Plate: Then runne out amaz'd,
Roaring, that all the Streete may know y'are rob'd.
Next threaten-to attach him and accuse him
Before a Iustice, and in th'end agree,
If hee restore the Plate, you'le giue the Chaine,
Otherwise not.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: But if wee bee discou'red!
For by his instruments and familiars
He can do much.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Lay all the fault on Trincalo.
But here's the maine point. If you can dissemble
Cunningly, and frame your countnance to expresse
Pitty and anger, that so learn'd a man
Should vse his friend so basely: If you can call
An out-cry well, roare high, and terrible.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: I'le fetch a cry from th'bottome of my heeles
But I'le roare loud enough; and thou must second mee
With wonder at the suddaine accident.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: But yours is the maine part, for as you play't
You win or loose the chaine.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: No more, no more, hee comes.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: SIgnior Pandolfo, three quarters of an houre
Render's your seruant perfectly transform'd.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Is he not wholy chang'd? what parts are wanting?

sp.speaker: AL.
sp.l: Antonio's shape hath cloath'd his bulk and visage,
Onely his hands and feete, so large and callous,
Require more time to supple.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Pray you sir
How long shall he retaine this metamorphosis?

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: The compleate circle of a naturall day.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: A naturall day? Are any daies vnnaturall?

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: I meane the revolution o'th' first mover,
Iust twice twelue houres, in which periode the rapt motion theeues, theeues!
Rowles all the Orbes from East to Occident.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Helpe, helpe, theeues, theeues, neighbours I am rob'd,

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: What a noise make you sir?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Haue I not reason
That thus am rob'd, theeues, theeues, call Constables,
The Watch, and Sergeants. Friends and Constables,
Neighbours I am vndone.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: This well begunne
So hee hold out still with a higher straine.
What ailes you sir?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Cricca my chamber's spoild
Of all my hangings, cloathes, and siluer plate.

sp.speaker: CRIC.
sp.l: Why this is brauely fain'd; continue sir.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Lay all the Gold-smithes, Keepers, Marshals, Bayliues.

sp.speaker: CRIC.
sp.l: Fye sir, your passion fall's, cry louder, roare
That all the Streete may heare.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Theeues, theeues, theeues!
All that I had is gone, and more then all.

sp.speaker: CRIC.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha: hold out, hold out; lay out a Lyons throate,
A little lowder.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: I can cry no longer,
My throate's sore, I am rob'd, I am rob'd, als gone.
Both my owne treasure, and the things I borrow'd.
Make thou an out-cry, I haue lost my voice:
Cry fire, and then they'l heare thee.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: good, good, theeues,
What ha you lost?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Wine, Iewels, Table-cloathes,
A cup-boord of rich plate.

sp.speaker: CRIC.
sp.l: Fye, you'le spoile all.
Now you out-do it. Say but a bowle or two.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Villaine, I say als gone; The room's as cleane
As a wip't Looking-glasse: ôj me, ôj me.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: What, in good earnest?

sp.speaker: PA.
sp.l: Foole in accursed earnest.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: You gull mee sure.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: The window towards the South stand's ope, from whence
Went all my treasure. Where's th'Astrologer?

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Here sir: and hardly can abstaine from laughing
To see you vex your selfe in vaine.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: In vaine Albumazar?
I left my plate with you, and 'tis all vanish't,
And you shall answer it.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: O! were it possible
By powre of Art, to check what Art hath done,
Your man should nere be chang'd: To wrong mee thus
With foule suspition of flat felonie?
Your Plate, your cloath of siluer, wine, and iewels,
Linnen, and all the rest, I gaue to Trincalo,
And for more safety, lock't them in the lobby.
Hee'le keepe them carefully. But as you loue your Mistresse
Disturbe him not this halfe houre, least you'le haue him
Like to a Centaure, halfe Clowne, halfe Gentleman.
Suffer his foote and hand that's yet vntouch't,
To be innobled like his other members.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Albumazar, I pray you pardon mee,
Th'vnlook'd-for barenesse of the roome amaz'd mee.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: How? thinke you me so negligent to commit
So rich a masse of treasure to th'open danger
Of a large casement, and suspitious Alley?
No sir, my sacrifice no sooner done
But I wrapt all vp safe, and gaue it Trincalo.
I could be angry, but that your suddaine feare
Excuses you. Fye, such a noise as this
Halfe an houre past, had skar'd th'intelligences,
And spoil'd the worke, but no harme done: go walke
Westward, directly Westward, one halfe houre:
Then turne back, and take your seruant turn'd t'antonio.
And as you like my skill performe your promise.
I meane the Chaine.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Content. Let's still go Westward,
Westward good Cricca, still directly Westward.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: HArpax. Furbo, and Ronca, come out, als cleere,
Why here's a noble prize worth ventring for.
Is not this brauer then sneake all night in danger,
Picking of lockes, or hooking cloathes at windoes?
Here's plate, and gold, and cloath, and meate and wine,
All rich: and easily got. Ronca stay here about,
And waite till Trincalo come forth: Then call him
With a low reuerence Antonio,
Giue him this gold with thankes, tell him he lent it
Before hee went to Barbary.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: How loose ten peeces?

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: There's a necessity in't, deuise some course
To get't againe: if not; our gaine's sufficient
To beare that losse. Furbo finde out Bavilona
The Curtezan, let her faine her selfe a Gentlewoman
Inamored of Antonio, bid her inuite him
To banket with her, and by all meanes possible
Force him stay there two houres.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.l: Why two houres?

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: That in that time thou maist conuey
Our treasure to the Inne, and speake a boate
Ready for Grauesend, and prouide a supper:
Where, with those pretious liquors, and good meates,
Wee'l cheere our selues; and thus well fed, and merry,
Take Boat by night.

sp.speaker: FVR.
sp.l: And what will you do?

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: First in and vsher out our changeling Trincalo:
Then finish vp a businesse of great profit,
Begun with a rich Marchant, that admires
My skill in Alchymie. I must not loose it.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Harpax bestow the plate, Furbo our beards,
Blacke patches for our eyes, and other properties,
And at the time and place meet all at Supper.

sp.speaker: AL.
sp.l: STand forth transform'd Antonio fully mued
From browne soare feathers of dull yeomanry
To th'glorious bloome of gentry; prune your selfe slick,
Sweare boldly y'are the man you represent
To all that dare deny't.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: I finde my thoughts
Most strangely altred; but me thinkes my face
Feeles still like Trincalo.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: You imagine so.
Senses are oft deceiu'd. As an attentiue Angler
Fixing his steady eyes on the swift streames
Of a steepe tumbling torrent, no sooner turnes
His sight to land, but giddy, thinkes the firme bankes
And constant trees, moue like the running waters:
So you that thirty yeares haue liu'd in Trincalo,
Chang'd suddenly, think y'are so still; but instantly
These thoughts will vanish.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Giue me a looking-glasse
To read your skill in these new lineaments.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: I'de rather giue you poyson: for a glasse
By secret power of crosse reflections,
And opticke vertue, spoiles the wondrous worke
Of transformation, and in a moment turnes you.
Spight of my skill, to Trincalo, as before.
We read that Apuleius by a rose
Chang'd from an Asse to Man: so by a mirrour,
You'l loose this noble lustre, and turne Asse.
I humbly take my leaue; but still remember
T'auoyd the Diuell and a looking glasse.
New-borne Antonio, I kisse your hands.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Divine Albumazar I kisse your hands.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: NOw am I grown a gentleman, and a fine one,
I know't by th'kissing of my hands so courtly,
My courteous knees bend in so true a distance,
As if my foot walk't in a frame of purpose.
Thus I accost you: or thus, sweet sir, your seruant:
Nay more, your seruants seruant: that's your grand-seruant.
I could descend from th'top of Pauls to th'bottome,
And on each step strew parting complements,
Striue for a doore while a good Carpenter
Might make a new one. I am your shadow sir,
And bound to wait vpon you. I'faith I will not: pray sir, &c.
O braue Albumazar!

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Iust Aesop's Crow, prink't vp in borrowed feathers.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: My veines are fild with newnesse: ô for a Chyrurgian
To ope this Arme, and view my gentle blood,
To try if't run two thousand pounds a yeare.
I feele my vnderstanding is enlarg'd
With the rare knowledge of this latter age.
A sacred fury ouer-swayes me. Prime!
Deale quickly, play, discard, I set ten shillings six pence.
You see't? my rest, fiue and fifty. Boy, more cards;
And as thou go'st, lay out some roaring oathes
For me; I'le pay thee againe with interest.
O braue Albumazar!

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: How his imagination boyles, and workes in all things
He euer saw or heard!

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: At gleeke? content.
A morneuall of Ases, gleeke of Knaues,
Iust nine apeece. Sir my gray Barbarie
'Gainst your dun cow, three traine sents and th'course,
For fiftie pound: as I am a gentleman
I'le meet next Cocking, and bring a haggard with me
That stoopes as free as lightning, strikes like thunder.
I lye? my reputation you shall heare on't.
O braue Albumazar!

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Hee'l grow starke mad I feare me.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Now I know
I am perfectly transform'd, my mind incites me
To chalenge some braue fellow for my credit,
And for more safety, get some friend in priuate
To take the businesse vp in peace and quiet.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Signior Antonio?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: There's not a crum of Trincalo.
In all this frame, but th'loue of Armellina:
Wer't not for thee I'de trauaile, and home againe
As wise as I went ouer.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Signior Antonio? welcome ten thousand times:
Blest be the Heau'ns and seas for your returne.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: I thanke you sir: Antonio is your seruant,
I am glad to see you wel. Fy, I kisse your hands: and thus accost you.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: This three months all your kindred, friends and children,
Mourn'd for your death.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: And so they well might do,
For fiue dayes I was vnder water; and at length
Got vp and spred my selfe vpon a chest,
Rowing with armes, and stearing with my feet;
And thus in fiue dayes more got land: beleeue it
I made a most incredible escape,
And safe returne from Barbarie: at your seruice.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Welcome ten thousand times from Barbarie.
No friend more glad to see Antonio
Then I: nor am I thus for hope of gaine;
But that I finde occasion to be gratefull
By your returne. Do you remember sir,
Before you went, as I was once arrested,
And could not put in baile; you passing by,
Lent me ten pound, and so discharg'd the debt?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Yes, yes, as well as 'twere but yesterday.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Oft haue I waited at your house with money,
And many thankes: but you were still beyond seas.
Now am I happy of this faire occasion
To testifie my honest care to pay you:
For you may need it.

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.l: Sir, I doe indeed,
Witnesse my treasure cast away by shipwracke.

sp.speaker: RO.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Is the gold good, for mine was good I lent you.

sp.speaker: RO.
sp.l: It was, and so is this. Signior Antonio, for this curtesie
Call me your seruant.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.p: Farewell good seruant, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha. I know not so much as his name! ten pound? this change is better then my birth: for in all the yeares of my yeomanry I could neuer yoke two crownes, and now I haue hearded ten faire twenty shilling peeces. Now will I goe to this Astrologer, and hire him turne my Cart to a Caroch, my foure Iades to two paire of Dutch mares, my mistres Armellina to a Lady, my Plow-boy Dick to two guarded foot-men: then will I hurry my selfe to the Mercers bookes, weare rich cloathes, be cal'd Tony by a great man, sell my lands, pay no debts, hate Citizens, and beate Sergeants: and when all failes, sneake out of Antonio with a two-peny looking-glasse, and turne as true Trincalo as euer.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.l: SIgnior Antonio, welcome.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: My life here's ten pound more. I thanke you heartily.

sp.speaker: HARP.
sp.l: Neuer in fitter season could I finde you.
If you remember sir, before you went
To Barbary, I lent you ten pound in gold.

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.l: Faith I remember no such thing excuse me.
What may I call your name?

sp.speaker: HARP.
sp.l: My name is Harpax,
Your friend and neighbour, of your old acquaintaince,

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.l: What Harpax! I am your seruant, I kisse your hands:
You must excuse me, you neuer lent me money.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.l: Sir, as I liue, ten twenty-shilling peeces.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Dangers at Sea, I find, haue hurt my memory.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.l: Why here's your owne hand-writing seal'd and sign'd,
In presence of your Cosen Iulio.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: 'Tis true, 'tis true; but I sustain'd great losses
By reason of the shipwracke. Here's fiue peeces,
Will that content you? and to morrow morning
Come to my house and take the rest.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.l: Well sir,
Though my necessity would importune you
For all, yet on your worships word, the rest
I'le call for in the morning. Farewell Antonio.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: I see we gentlemen can sometime borrow
As well as lend, and are as loath to pay
As meaner men. I'le home, lest other creditors
Call for the rest.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: SIgnior Antonio? I saw you as you landed,
And in great hast follow'd to congratulate
Your safe returne, with these most wish't embraces.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: And I accept your ioy with like affection.
How do you call your selfe?

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Haue you forgot
Your deere friend Ronca, whom you lou'd so well?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: O I remember now my deere friend Ronca.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Thanks to the fortune of the seas that sau'd you.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: I feare I owe him money: how shall I shift him?
How do's your body Ronca?

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: My deere Antonio,
Neuer so well as now I haue the power
Thus to embrace my friend, whom all th'Exchange
Gaue drown'd for three whole months. My deere Antonio.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: RO.
sp.l: I thank you.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: While my deere Ronca
Clipt me, my purse shooke dangerously; yet both his armes
And hands embrac'd my necke: here's none behinde me,
How can this be?

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Most deare Antonio,
Was not your passage dangerous from Barbarie?
We had great windes and tempests; and I feare me,
You felt the force at sea.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Yes dearest Ronca.
How's this? I see his hands, and yet my purse is gone.

sp.speaker: RO.
sp.l: Signior Antonio, I see your mind's much troubled
About affaires of worth; I take my leaue,
And kisse your hands of liberalitie.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: And kisse my hands of liberalitie?
I gaue him nothing: O my purse, my purse!
Deare master Ronca.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: What's your pleasure sir?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Shew me your hand.

sp.speaker: RO.
sp.l: Here 'tis.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: But where's th'other?

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Why here.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: But I meane where's your other hand?

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Thinke you me the Giant with a hundred hands?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Giue me your right.

sp.speaker: RO.
sp.l: My right?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Your left.

sp.speaker: RO.
sp.l: My left?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Now both.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: There's both my deere Antonio▪
Keepe your selfe darke, eate broath; your fearefull passage,
And want of naturall rest hath made you franticke.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Villaine, rogue, cut-purse, theefe, deare Ronca stay: hee's gone
I'th Diuels name, how could this fellow do it?
I felt his hands fast lock't about my necke;
And still he spoke, it could not be his mouth
For that was full of deere Antonio.
My life he stol't with's feet: such a tricke more
Will worke worse with me then a looking-glasse.
To loose fiue pound in curt'sie, and the rest
In salutation!

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Signior Antonio,
What ailes you?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Ronca a rogue, a cut-purse,
Hath rob'd mee of fiue twenty-shilling peeces.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: What kind of man was he? something like me?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Had such a theeuish countenance as your owne,
But that he wore a black patch ore his eye.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Met you with Ronca? 'tis the cunningst nimmer
Of the whole company of cut-purse hall▪
I am sorry I was not here to warne you of him.

sp.speaker: BE.
sp.l: FVrbo no more, vnlesse thy words were charmes
Of power to reuiue him: Antonio's dead.
Hee's dead, and in his death hath buried
All my delights: my eares are deafe to musicke
