That sounds of pleasure: sing then the doleful'st notes
That er'e were set by melancholy: O Antonio!
Flow streames of liquid salt from my sad eyes,
To celebrate his mournfull exequies.
Antonio's dead, hee's dead, and I remaine
To draw my poore life in continuall paine,
Till it haue paid to his sad memory
Dutie of loue: ô then most willingly
Drown'd with my teares, as hee with waues, I dye.

sp.speaker: BE.
sp.l: Breake thy sad strings, and instrument: O strange! hee's here.
Signior Antonio! my heart's sweet content!
My life and better portion of my soule!
Are you return'd? and safe? for whose sad death
I spent such streames of teares, and gusts of sighes?
Or is't my loue, that to my longing fancy
Frames your desired shape, and mockes my senses?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Whom do you talke withal faire gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: BE.
sp.l: With my best friend, commander of my life,
My most belou'd Antonio.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: With me?
What's your desire with me sweet Lady?

sp.speaker: BE.
sp.l: Sir to command me, as you haue done euer,
To what you please: for all my libertie
Lies in your seruice.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Now I smell the businesse.
This is some gentlewoman inamored
With him whose shape I beare: Fie, what an Asse
Was I to strange my selfe, and loose th'occasion
Of a good banquet, and her companie?
Il'e mend it as I can. Madame I did but iest
To try if absence caus'd you to forget
A friend that lou'd you euer.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.l: Forget Antonio,
Whose deare remembrance doth informe the soule
Of your poore seruant Beuilona? no,
No, had you dy'd, it had not quench't one sparke
Of th'sweet affection which your loue hath kindled
In this warme breast.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Madam, the waues had drown'd mee.
But that your loue held vp my chin.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.l: Wil't please you
Enter, and rest your selfe, refresh the wearinesse
Of your hard trauell: I haue good wine and fruits,
My husband's out of towne: you shall command
My house, & all that's in't.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Why are you married?

sp.speaker: BE.
sp.l: Haue you forgot my husband? an angry roarer?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: O I remember him: but if he come?

sp.speaker: BE.
sp.l: Whence growes this feare? how come you so respectfull?
You were not wont be numb'd with such a coldnesse.
Go in sweet life, go in.

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.l: O! I remember while I liu'd in Barbary
A pretty song the Moores sing to a gridiron:
Sweet Madame by your fauour I'le sing't to this.
Alcoch Dolash, &c. Thus 'tis in English.
My heart in flames doth fry
Of thy beauty,
While I
Dy.
Fy?
And why
Shouldst thou deny
Me thy sweet company?
My braines to teares do flow
While all below
Doth glow.
O!
Foe
If so,
How canst thou go
About to say me no?
This the Moores call two wings vpon a Gridiron.
But it goes sweeter farre 'oth' iron Instrument.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.l: There's one within my Kitchin ready strung: go in.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Sweete Lady pardon mee, I'le follow you.
Happy Antonio in so rare a Mistresse!
But happier I, that in his place enioye her:
I say still, there's no pleasure like Transforming.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: NOw is the Asse expecting of a banquet,
Ready to court, embrace, and kisse his Mistresse.
But I'le soone staue him. Tick, tock, what ho!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.l: Who's that so boldly knocks? I am not within;
Or busy: Why so importunate? who is't?

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: 'Tis I.

sp.speaker: BE.
sp.l: Your name?

sp.speaker: RO.
sp.l: Thomas vp William, vp Morgan, vp Dauie, vp Roger, &c.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Spinola's Campe's broke loose: a troupe of Souldiers!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.l: Oj me! my Husband! Oj me wretch, 'tis my Husband.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: One man, and weare so many names!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.l: O sir,
'Has more out-ragious deuils in his rage,
Then names. As you respect your life, auoide him.
Downe at that window.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: 'Tis as high as Paules.
Open the Garden dore.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.l: He 'has the keyes.
Downe at some window, as you loue your life,
Tender my honour, and your safety.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Beuilona?
Downe, or I'le breake the dores, and with the splinters
Beate all thy bones to peeces: Downe you whore!

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.l: Be patient but a little; I come instantly.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Ha'you no trunck nor chest to hide mee?

sp.speaker: BE.
sp.l: None sir.
Alas I am cleane vndone, it is my Husband.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Doubtlesse, this whore hath some of her companions
That wrong mee thus. But if I catch the villaine,
Il'e bath my hungry sword, and sharpe reuenge,
In his heart-bloud. Come downe.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.l: I cannot stay.
There stands an empty Hogshead with a false bottome
To ope and shut at pleasure: come hither, in,
In, as you loue your life.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: But heare you Madam,
Is there no looking-glasse within't, for I hate glasses
As naturally, as some do Cats, or Cheese.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.l: In, in, there's none.

sp.speaker: RO.
sp.l: Who now? Is the Asse past?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.l: I tunn'd him vp, ha, ha, ha, I feare hee'le fall a working.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Second me hansomely, wee'le entertaine him
An houre or two, and laugh and get his cloath's
To make our sport vp. Wife, where's the empty hogshead
That wont to stand vnder the staires?

sp.speaker: BE.
sp.l: There still.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Out with it quickly: I must haue it fil'd.

sp.speaker: BE.
sp.l: Not to day, good sir, to morrow will serue as well.

sp.speaker: RO.
sp.l: I must ha't now.

sp.speaker: BE.
sp.l: 'Tis more then I can cary.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: I'le helpe thee: so, so. Foh! this vessel's musty.
Fetch out some water.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.l: Fetch't your selfe.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Pox of all Transmutation, I am smother'd.
Lady, as you loue mee, giue the Hogshead vent.
The beere that's in't will worke and breake the vessell.

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.l: Signior Antonio, as you loue your life
Lie still and close, for if you stirre you die.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: So, so, now shake it, so, so.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Oh I am drown'd, I drowne!

sp.speaker: RO.
sp.l: Whence come's this hollow sound?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: I drowne, I smother!

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: My life 'tis Trincalo, For I haue heard that Coxcombe,
That Asse, that Clowne, seekes to corrupt my wife,
Sending his fruite and dainties from the Country.
O that 'twere he. How would I vse the villaine!
First crop his eares, then slit his nose, and gueld him,
And with a red hot Iron seare his raw wounds;
Then barrell him againe, and send the Eunuch
To the great Turk to keep his Concubines. Tick, tock, who's within heere?

sp.speaker: BEV.
sp.l: One that you dare not touch.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: One that I dare not?
Out villaine, out. Signior Antonio!
Had it beene any but your selfe, hee had died.
But as you sau'd my life before you went,
So now command mine in your seruices.
I would haue sworne y'ad drown'd in Barbary.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: 'Twas a hard passage: but not so dangerous
As was this Vessell. Pray you conceiue no ill,
I meant no harme, but cal'd at your wife to know
How my sonne Lelio did, and daughter Flauia.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Sir I beleeue you.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: But I must tell you one thing,
You must not be so iealous, on my honour
Shee's very honest.

sp.speaker: RO.
sp.l: For you I make no question.
But there's a rogue cal'd Trincalo, whom if I catch.
I'le teach him.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Who? you meane Pandolfo's Farmer.
Alas poore foole, hee's a stark Asse, but harmelesse.
And though she talk with him, 'tis but to laugh,
As all the world do's at him: Come be friends
At my entreaty.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Sir, for your sake.

sp.speaker: BE.
sp.l: I thanke you.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Let's haue a fire; and while I dry my selfe,
Prouide good wine and meate. I'le dine with you.
I must not home thus wet. I am something bold with you.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: My house and selfe are at your seruice.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Lead in.
Alas poore, Trincalo had'st thou beene taken,
Thou hadst bene tunn'd for Turky. Ha; ha, ha; faire fall Antonio's shape.
What a notorious Wittall's this! Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO.
sp.l: THvs by great fauour of propitious Starres,
From fearefull stormes, ship-wrack, and raging billowes,
Mercilesse iawes of death, am I return'd
To th'safe and quiet bosome of my Country,
And wish'd embracements of my friends and kindred.
The memory of these misfortunes past,
Season's the welcome, and augment's the pleasure
I shall receiue of my sonne Lelio,
And daughter Flauia. So doth alloy
Make gold, that else were vselesse, seruiceable.
So th'rugged fore-head of a threatning Mountaine,
Threatens the smoothnesse of a smiling Valley.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: WHat do I see? Is not this Trincalo
Transform'd t'antonio? 'tis: and so perfectly
That did the right Antonio now confront him,
I'de sweare they both were true, or both were false.

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: This man admires the vnexpectednesse
Of my returne.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: O wondrous powre of Starres,
And skill of Art t'apply 't. You that are married
May iustly feare, least this Astrologer
Cloath your wiues seruants in your shape, and vse you
As Iupiter did Amphitrio: You that are rich,
In your owne forme may loose your gold.

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: 'Tis Cricca.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Hee seeme's so iust the man hee represent's,
That I dare hardly vse him as I purpos'd.

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: Cricca, well met, how fares my friend Pandolfo?

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Your friend Pandolfo? How are your meanes improu'd;
To stile familiarly your Maister friend?

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: What saist thou?

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: That I reioyce your Worship's safe return'd
From your late drowning. Th'Exchange hath giu'n you lost.
And all your friends worne mourning three monthes past.

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: The danger of the Shipwrack I escap't
So desperate was, that I may truely say
I am new borne, not sau'd.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, through what a grace
And goodly countenance, the Raskall speakes?
What a graue portance? Could Antonio
Himselfe out-do him? ô you notorious villaine!
Who would haue thought thou couldst haue thus dissembled?

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: How now? a seruant thus familiar? Syrrha
Vse your companions so: more reuerence
Become's you better.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: As though I vnderstood not,
The end of all this plot and goodly businesse?
Come I know all, see! this vntil'd clod of earth
Conceites his minde transform'd, as well as body.
Hee wringes and bites his lips for feare of laughing. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: Why laugh you sirra?

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Sirra, to see thee chang'd
So strangely, that I can not spy one inch
Of thy old Clownish Carkas. Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: Laughter proceeds
From absurd actions that are harmelesse.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.
Sententious Block-head!

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: And y'are ill aduis'd
To iest in steed of pitty. Alas! my miseries,
Dangers of death, slau'ry of cruell Moores,
And tedious iournies, might haue easly altred
A stronger body; much more this decay'd vessell,
Out-worne with age, and broken by misfortunes.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Leaue your set speeches. Go to Antonio's house,
Effect your businesse. For vpon my credite
Th'art so well turn'd, they dare not but accept thee.

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: Where should I hope for welcome, if not there;
From my owne house, children, and family?

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Is't possible this. Coxcombe should conceiue
His mind transform'd? How grauely he continues
The countnance hee began? Ha, ha. Why block-head?
Think'st to deceiue mee too? Why Trincalo?

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: I vnderstand you not. Hands off.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Art not thou Trincalo,
Pandolfo's man?

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: I not so much as know him.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Dar'st thou denie't to mee?

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: I dare, and must
To all the world, 'long as Antonio liues.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: You arrant Asse, haue not I knowne thee serue
My Maister in his Farme this thirteene yeares?

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: By all the oathes that bind mens consciences
To truth, I am Antonio; and no other.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: WHat meanes this noise? ô Cricca! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Sir heare's your Farmer Trincalo, transform'd
So iust, as he were melted, and new cast
In the true mould of old Antonio.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Th'right eye's no liker to the left, then hee
To my good neighbour. Diuine Albumazar!
How I admire thy skill! iust so hee look't,
And thus hee walk't; this is his face, his haire,
His eies, and countnance; If his voyce be like
Then is th'Astrologer a wonder-worker.

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: Signior Pandolfo, I thanke the heauens as much
To finde you well, as for my owne returne.
How do's your daughter, and my loue, Sulpitia?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Well, well, sir.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: This is a good beginning,
How naturally the rogue dissembles it?
With what a gentle garbe, and ciuill grace
He speake's and lookes: How cunningly Albumazar
Hath for our purpose suted him in Barbary cloaths. I'le try him further: Sir,
We heard you were drown'd, pray you, how scap't you ship-wrack?

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: No sooner was I ship't for Barbary,
But faire winde follow'd, and faire weather led vs.
When entred in the Straites of Gibraltar,
The heau'ns, and seas, and earth, conspir'd against vs,
The tempest tore our helme, and rent our tackels,
Broake the maine Mast, while all the sea about vs
Stood vp in watry Mountaines to ouerwhelme vs.
And struck's against a Rock, splitting the vessell
T'a thousand splinters. I, with two Marriners
Swam to the Coast, where by the barbarous Moores
We were surpriz'd, fetter'd, and sold for slaues.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: This tale th'Astrologer pen'd, and he hath cond it.

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: But by a Gentleman of Italy
Whom I had knowne before.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: No more, this tast
Proue's thou canst play the rest. For this faire story
My hand I make thy ten pound, twenty Markes.
Thou look'st and speak'st so like Antonio.

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: Whom should I looke, and speake like, but my selfe?

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Good still.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: But now my honest Trincalo,
Tell mee, where's all the Plate, the gold, and Iewels,
That the Astrologer, when hee had transform'd thee
Committed to thy charge? are they safe lock't?

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: I vnderstand you not.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: The iewels man,
The Plate and gold th'Astrologer that chang'd thee
Bad thee lay vp?

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: What plate? what gold? what Iewels.
What transformation? what Astrologer?

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Leaue of Antonio now, and speake like Trincalo.

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: Leaue of your iesting; it neither fits your place
Nor age, Pandoflo, to scoffe your ancient friend.
I know not what you meane by gold and iewels,
Nor by th'Astrologer, nor Trincalo.

sp.speaker: CRIC.
sp.l: Better and better still. Beleeue mee sir,
Hee thinke's himselfe Antonio, and euer shall bee,
And so possesse your Plate. Art not thou Trincalo
My Maisters Farmer?

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: I am Antonio
Your Master's friend, if hee teach you more manners.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Humour of wiuing's gone: farewel good Flauia,
Three thousand pound must not bee lost so slightly.
Come sir, wee'l drag you to th'Astrologer,
And turne you to your ragged barke of Yeomanry.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: To me these tearmes!

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Come I'le not loose my Plate.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Stay, sir, and take my counsell. Let him still
Firmely conceite himselfe the man hee seeme's:
Thus hee himselfe deceiu'd, will farre more earnestly
Effect your businesse, and deceiue the rest.
There's a maine difference twixt a selfe-bred action
And a for'st carriage. Suffer him then to enter
Antonio's house: and waite th'euent: for him
He cannot scape: What you entend to do,
Do't when 'has seru'd your turne. I see the Maide,
Let's hence least they suspect our consultations.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Thy counsel's good: Away.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Looke Trincalo
Yonder's your beauteous Mistresse Armellina,
And daughter Flauia. Courage, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: Blest be the heau'ns, that rid me of this trouble.
For with their Farmer and Astrologer,
Plate, and gold, the'aue almost madded mee.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: ARmellina?

sp.speaker: ARM.
sp.l: Mistresse.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Is the dore fast?

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: Yes, as an Vsurers purse.

sp.speaker: FL.
sp.l: Come hither wench.
Looke here, there's Trincalo, Pandolfo's Farmer
Wrapt in my father's shape: prethee come quickly,
And help mee to abuse him.

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: Notorious Clowne!

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: These are my gates, and that's the Cabinet
That keepes my Iewels, Lelio, and his sister.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Neuer was villany so personate
In seemely properties of grauity.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Tick, tock.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Who's hee that knock's so boldly?

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: What want you, sir?

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: O my faire daughter Flauia! Let all the Starres
Powre downe full blessings on thee. Ope the dores.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Marke! his faire daughter Flauia ha, ha, ha.
Most shamelesse villaine how hee counterfeits!

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Know'st not thy father, old Antonio?
Is all the world growne frantick?

sp.speaker: FL.
sp.l: What Antonio?

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Thy louing father, Flauia.

sp.speaker: FL.
sp.l: My father!
Would thou wert in his place. Antonio's dead,
Dead, vnder water drown'd.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: That dead and drown'd
Am I.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: I loue not to conuerse with dead men.

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: Open the dore sweete Flauia.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Sir I am afear'd:
Horrour incloses mee, my haires stand vp,
I sweate to heare a dead man speake, you smell
Of putrifaction: Fy I feel't hither.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Th'art much abus'd, I liue: come downe, and know mee.

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: Mistresse let mee haue some sport too. Who's there?

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Let mee come in.

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: Soft, soft sir, Y'are too hasty.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Quickly, or else—

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: Good words, good words, I pray sir,
In strangers houses! were the dores your owne,
You might bee bolder.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: I'le beate the dores and windowe's
About your eares.

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: Are you so hot? wee'le coole you.
Since your late drowning, your gray and reuerent head
Is smear'd with Oes, and stucke with Cockle-shels,
This is to wash it.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Impudent whoore!

sp.speaker: ARM.
sp.l: Out Carter.
Hence durtie whipstocke, hence you foule clowne: be gone,
Or all the water I can make, or borrow,
Shall once more drowne you.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: ARmellina? whom do you draw your tongue vpon so sharply?

sp.speaker: ARM.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis your fathers ghost, that striues by force
To breake the doores and enter.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: This his graue lookes!
In every lineament himselfe no liker.
Had I not haply been advertiz'd,
What could haue forc'd me thinke 'twere Trincalo?
Doubtlesse, th'Astrologer hath rais'd a ghost
That walkes in th'reverend ghost of my dead father.

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: These ghosts, these Trincalo's, and Astrologers,
Strike me beside my selfe. Who will receiue me
When mine owne sonne refuseth? ô Antonio!

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: Infinite power of Art! who would beleeue
The planets influence could transforme a man
To seuerall shapes! I could now beate him soundly
But that he weares the awfull countenance
Of my dead father, whose memory I reverence.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: If I be chang'd beyond thy knowledge, sonne,
Consider that th'excesse of heate in Barbarie,
The feare of shipwrack, and long tedious iournies,
Haue tan'd my skin, and shrunk my eyes and cheekes;
Yet still this face, though alter'd, may be knowne.
This skarre beares witnesse, 'twas the wound thou cur'dst
With thine owne hands.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: He that chang'd Trincalo
T' Antonio's figure, omitted not the skarre
As a maine character.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: I haue no other markes
Or reasons to perswade thee; me thinkes, this word
I am thy father, were argument sufficient
To bend my knees, and creepe to my embracements.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: A sudden coldnesse strikes me, my tender heart
Beates with compassion of I know not what.
Sirra be gone, trusse vp your goodly speeches,
Sad shipwracks, and strange transformations.
Your plot's discouer'd, 'twill not take: thy impudence
For once I pardon. The pious reuerence.
I owe to th'graue resemblance of my father
Holds backe my angry hands. Hence, if I catch you
Haunting my doores againe, I'le bastonado you
Out of Antonio's skin. Away.

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: I goe sir,
And yeeld to such crosse fortune as thus driues me.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: When this transformed substance of my carcasse
Did liue imprison'd in a wanton hogshead,
My name was Don Antonio, and that title
Preseru'd my life, and chang'd my sute of cloathes.
sp.p: How kindly the good Gentlewoman vs'd me! with what respect and carefull tendernesse! Your worship sit had euer a sickly constitution, and I feare much more now since your long travaile▪ as you loue me, off with these wet things, and put on the sute you left with me before you went to Barbary. Good sir neglect not your health: for vpon my experience there's nothing worse for the rheume, then to bee drench't in a musty hogshead. Pretty soule! such another speech would haue drawn off my legges and armes, as easily as hose and doublet. Had I been Trincalo I'de haue sworne th'had cheated. But fy! 'tis base and clownish to suspect, and a gentlewomans freenesse to part with a cast sute. Now to the businesse. I'le in to my owne house, and first bestow Armellina vpon Trincalo, then try what can bee done for Pandolfo: for 'tis a rule I wont t'obserue. First doe your own affaires, and next your masters. This word master makes me doubt I am not chang'd as I should be. But als one, I'le venter, and doe something worthy Antonio's name while I haue it.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: WRetched Antonio, hast beene preseru'd so strangely
From forraine miseries to be wrong'd at home?
Bar'd from thy house by th'scornes of thine owne children?

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.l: Tick, tock.

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: But stay, there's on knockes boldly, may be some friend.

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.l: Tick, tock.

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: Dwell you here gentleman?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Hee cals me gentleman.
See th'vertue of good cloathes: all men salute,
Honour, respect and reverence vs.

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: Yong gentleman,
Let me without offence intreate your name,
And why you knocke.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: How sirra Sawce-boxe, my name?
Or thou some stranger art, or grossely ignorant
That know'st not me. Ha! what art thou that ask'st it?

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: Bee not in choler sir.

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.l: Befits it me,
A gentleman of publicke reputation,
To stoope so low as satisfie the questions
Of base and earthly peeces like thy selfe? What art thou? ha?

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: Th'vnfortunate possessor of this house.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Thou ly'st base Sycophant, my worship owes it.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: 'May be my sonne hath sold it in my absence,
Thinking me dead. How long has't cal'd you master?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: 'Long as Antonio possest it.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Which Antonio?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Antonio Anastasio.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: That Anastasio,
That selfe same man am I: I scap'd by swimming,
And now returne to keepe my former promise
Of Flauia to Pandolfo; and in exchange,
To take Sulpitia to my wife.

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: All this
I intended 'fore I went; but sir, if I
Can be no other then my selfe, and you
Are that Antonio, you and I are one.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: How? one with thee? speake such another sillable,
And by the terror of this deadly steele,
That nere saw light, but sent to endlesse darknesse
All that durst stand before't: thou diest.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Alas
My weaknesse growne by age, and paines of trauell,
Dissarmes my courage to defend my selfe;
I haue no strength but patience.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: What art now?

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Peter, and Thomas, William, what you please.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: What boldnesse madded thee to steale my name?

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Sir, heat of wine.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: And sirra when y'are drunk,
Is there no person to put on, but mine,
To couer your intended villanies?

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: But good sir, if I be not I, who am I?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: An Oxe, an Asse, a dog.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Strange negligence
To loose my selfe! me thinkes I liue and moue,
Remember. Could the fearefull apprehension
Of th'vgly feare of drowning so transforme me?
Or did I dye, and by Pythagoras rule,
My soule's prouided of another lodging?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Be what thou wilt, except Antonio,
'Tis death to touch that name.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Dangers at sea
Are pleasures, weigh'd with these home-iniuries.
Was euer man thus skar'd beside himselfe?
O most vnfortunate Antonio!
At sea thou suffredst shipwrack of thy goods,
At land of thine owne selfe. Antonio?
Or what name else they please? fly, fly to Barbarie,
And rather there endure the forraigne crueltie
Of fetters, whippes, and Moores, then here at home
Be wrong'd and baffled by thy friends and children.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: How? prating still? why Timothy, be gone,
Or draw, and lay Antonio downe betwixt vs,
Let fortune of the fight decide the question.
Here's a braue rogue, that in the Kings high-way
Offers to robbe me of my good name. Draw.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: These wrongs recall my strength, I am resolu'd.
Better dye once, then suffer alwayes. Draw.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Stay. Vnderstand'st thou well nice points of duell?
Art borne of gentle bloud, and pure discent?
Was none of all thy linage hang'd, or cuckold?
Bastard, or bastinado'd? is thy pedigree
As long and wide as mine? For otherwise
Thou wert most vnworthy; and 'twere losse of honour
In me to fight. More, I haue drawne fiue teeth:
If thine stand sound, the tearmes are much vnequall.
And by strict lawes of duell, I am excus'd
To fight on disadvantage.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: This some Asse!

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: If we concurre in all, write a formall chalenge,
And bring thy second: meane while I'le make prouision
Of Calais sand to fight vpon securely. Ha!

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: AM I awake? or do deceitfull dreames
Present to my wild fansie things I see not?

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Sir, what amazement's this? why wonder you?

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: See'st thou not Trincalo and Antonio?

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: O strange! th'are both heere.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: Didst not thou informe me,
That Trincalo was turn'd t'antonio?
Which I beleeuing, like a cursed sonne,
With most reprochfull threats, droue mine old father
From his owne doores; and yet rest doubtfull, whether
This be the true Antonio: 'may be th'Astrologer
Hath chang'd some other, and not Trincalo.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: No, feare it not: 'tis plaine: Albumazar
Hath cheated my old master of his plate.
For here's the Farmer, as like himselfe as euer;
Onely his cloathes excepted. Trincalo!

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Cricca, where's Trincalo? do'st see him here?

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Yes, and as ranke an Asse as e're he was.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Thou'rt much deceiu'd, thou neither see'st nor know'st me.
I am transform'd, transform'd.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Th'art still thy selfe.
Lelio, this Farmer's halfe a foole, halfe knaue.
And as Pandolfo did with much intreatie
Perswade him to transforme; so as much labour
Will hardly bring the Coxcombe to himselfe,
That nere was out on't. Who art, if not hee?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: My name is Don Antonio, I am now going
To my owne house, to giue Pandolfo Flauia,
And Armellina to his Farmer Trincalo.
How dar'st thou Cricca, but a meaner seruant,
Resemble me, a man of worth and worship,
To such a clowne as Trincalo, a branded foole,
An Asse, a laughing-stock to Towne and Countrey?
Art not asham'd to name him with Antonio?

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: Do not thy actions, with thy rude behauiour,
Proclaime thee what thou art?

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Notorious clowne!

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Villaine, th'hast broke my shoulders.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: O did'st feele him?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: I with a poxe.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: Then th'art still Trincalo.
For hadst thou beene Antonio, he had smarted.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: I feele it as I am Antonio.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Foole! who loues Armellina?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: 'Tis I, 'tis I.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Antonio neuer lou'd his kitchin-maid.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Well, I was taken for Antonio,
And in his name receiu'd ten pound in gold,
Was by his mistresse entertain'd; but thou
Enuy'st my happinesse: if th'hast th'ambition
To rise as I haue done: Go to Albumazar,
And let him change thee to a Knight, or Lord.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Note the strange power of strong imagination.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: A world of engines cannot wrest my thoughts,
From being a Gentleman: I am one, and will be:
And though I bee not, yet will thinke my selfe so:
And scorne thee Cricca, as a slaue and seruant.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: TIs but lost labour to disswade his dulnesse,
Beleeue me that's your father.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: When I droue him thence,
Spight of my bloud his reuerent countenance
Strooke me t'a deepe compassion. To cleere all,
I'le aske one question. Signior Antonio,
What money tooke you when you went your voyage?

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: As I remember, fourescore and fifteene pound
In Barbarie gold. Had Lucio kept his word
I had carried iust a hundred.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: Pardon me, father;
'Twas my blind ignorance, not want of duty,
That wrong'd you: all was intended for a Farmer,
Whom an Astrologer, they sayd, transform'd.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: How an Astrologer?

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: When you parted hence
It seemes you promis'd Flauia to Pandolfo.
Newes of your death arriuing, th'old Gentleman
Importunes me to second what you purpos'd.
Consulting therefore with my friends and kindred,
Loth my yong sister should be buried quicke
I'th graue of threescore yeares: by their aduice
I fully did deny him. He chafes and stormes,
And finds at length a cunning man, that promis'd
To turne his Farmer to your shape: and thus
Possesse your house, and giue him Flauia.
Whereof I warn'd, wrong'd you in stead of Trincalo.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Then hence it came they cald me Trincalo,
And talk't of an Astrologer; which names
Almost inrag'd me past my selfe and senses.
'Tis true I promis'd, but haue oft repented it.
And much more since he goes about to cheate me.
He must not haue her, sir.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: I am glad y'are so resolu'd.
And since, with vs, you finde that match vnequall,
Let's all intreate you to bestow your daughter
Vpon his sonne Eugenio.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Sonne, at your pleasure
Dispose of Flauia, with my full consent.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: And as you iudge him worthy your daughter Flauia,
Thinke me no lesse of his Sulpitia.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: I do; and euer had desire to match
Into that family; and now I finde my selfe
Old, weake, vnfit for marriage, you shall enioy her,
If I can worke Pandolfo by intreatie:

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: To deale with him with reason and intreaties,
Is to perswade a mad-man: for his loue
Makes him no lesse. All speeches opposite
T'his fixt desire, and loue-corrupted iudgement,
Seeme extreame fooleries. Will hee consent
To giue his daughter to your sonne, and you
Deny him Flauia? Shall Eugenio
Expect or land or loue from old Pandolfo,
Being his open riuall? 'tis impossible.
He sought to cosen you; therefore resolue
To pay him in's owne money. Be but aduis'd
By my poore counsaile, and one stroke shall cut
The root of his designes, and with his arrowes
Strike his owne plot so dead, that Albumazar
With all his starres and instruments, shall neuer
Giue it fresh motion.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Cricca, to thy direction
We yeeld our selues, manage vs at thy pleasure.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: Speake quickly Cricca.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: The ground of all this businesse,
Is to catch Trincalo, and locke him fast
Till I release him: next, that no man whisper
Th'least word of your returne. Then will I home,
And with a cheerefull looke tell my old master,
That Trincalo— but stay, looke where he comes,
Let's in, and there at leasure I'le informe you
From poynt to poynt. Lelio, detaine him here,
Till I send Armellina downe to second you.
Crosse him in nothing, call him Antonio,
And good enough.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: Feare not, let me alone.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: THis rascall Cricca with his arguments
Of malice, so disturbes my gentle thoughts,
That I halfe doubt I am not what I seeme:
But that will soone bee clear'd; if they receiue mee
In at Antonio's house, I am Antonio.

sp.speaker: LEL.
sp.l: Signior Antonio my most louing father?
Blest be the day and houre of your returne.

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.l: Son Lelio? a blessing on my child, I pray thee tell mee,
How fares my seruant Armellina? well?

sp.speaker: LEL.
sp.l: Haue you forgot my sister Flauia?

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.l: What my deere daughter Flauia? no, but first
Call Armellina: for this day wee'l celebrate
A gleeke of Marriages: Pandolfo and Flauia,
Sulpitia and my selfe, and Trincalo
With Armellina. Call her, good Lelio, quickly.

sp.speaker: LEL.
sp.l: I will sir.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: So: this is well that Lelio
Confesseth mee his father. Now I am perfect,
Perfect Antonio.

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: SIgnior Antonio!
My long expected Maister!

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: O Armellina!
Come let mee kisse thy brow like my owne daughter.

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: Sir 'tis too great a fauour. I kisse your foote.
What falne? Alas! how feeble you are growne,
With your long trauel?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: True; and being drown'd,
Nothing so grieu'd mee as to loose thy company.
But since I am safe return'd, for thy good seruice
I'le helpe thee to a husband.

sp.speaker: ARM.
sp.l: A husband, sir?
Some yong and lusty youth, or else I'le none.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: To one that loue's thee deerely, deerely wench.
A goodly man, like mee in limbs and fashion.

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: Fye, an old man? how? cast my selfe away,
And bee no nurse but his?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Hee's not like mee
In yeares and grauity, but faire proportion.
A hansome well-set man as I.

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: His name?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: 'Tis Tom Trincalo of Totnam,

sp.speaker: ARM.
sp.l: Signior Pandolfo's lusty Farmer?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: That's hee.

sp.speaker: ARM.
sp.l: Most vnexpected happinesse! 'tis the man,
I more esteeme then my owne life: sweete Maister
Procure that match, and thinke mee satisfyed
For all my former seruice without wages.
But as I feare you iest. My poore vnworthinesse
Hopes not so great a fortune as sweete Trincalo.
No, wretched Armellina, in and despaire:
Back to thy mournefull Dresser; there lament
Thy flesh to Kitchin-stuffe, and bones to ashes,
For loue of thy sweet Farmer.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Alas poore soule,
How prettily shee weepes for mee! Wilt see him?

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: My soule waites in my eies, and leaues my body
Senselesse.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Then sweare to keep my counsell.

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: I sweare
By th'beauteous eies of Trincalo.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Why I am Trincalo.

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: Your worship sir! why do you flout your seruant,
Right worshipfull Antonio, my reuerend Maister?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Pox of Antonio, I am Tom Trincalo.
Why laugh'st thou?

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: 'Tis desire and ioy,
To see my sweetest.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Look vpon mee and see him.

sp.speaker: ARM.
sp.l: I say I see Antonio, and none other.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: I am within, thy loue; without, thy Maister.
Th'Astrologer transform'd mee for a day.

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: Mock not your poore Maide, pray you sir.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: I doe not.
Now would I break this head against the stones,
To be vnchang'd; fye on this Gentry, it stick's
Like Bird-lime, or the Pox. I can not part with't.
Within, I am still thy Farmer Trincalo.

sp.speaker: ARM.
sp.l: Then must I waite, till old Antonio
Bee brought to bed of a faire Trincalo;
Or flea you, and strip you to yourselfe againe.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Carry mee to your chamber. Try mee there.

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: O sir by no meanes: but with my louely Farmer
I'de stay all night and thank him.

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.l: Crosse misfortune!
Accurst Albumazar! and mad Pandolfo!
To change me thus, that when I most desire
To bee my selfe, I cannot. Armellina!
Fetch mee a looking-glasse.

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: To what end?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Fetch one.
Let my old maisters businesse sink or swim,
This sweet occasion must not be neglected.
Now shall I know th'Astrologers skill: ô wonderfull!
Admir'd Albumazar in two transmutations:
Here's my old Farmers face. How in an instant
I am vnchang'd that was so long a changing. Here's my flatte nose againe, &c.
Now Armellina take thy lou'd Trincalo
To thy desir'd embracements, vse thy pleasure,
Kisse him thy belly-full.

sp.speaker: ARM.
sp.l: Not here in publick.
T'enioy too soone what pleaseth is vnpleasant:
The world would enuy that my happinesse.
Go in, I'le follow you, and in my bed-chamber
Wee'l consummate the match in priuacie.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Was not the face I wore, farre worse then this?
But for thy comfort, Wench, Albumazar
Hath died my thoughts so deep i'th' graine of Gentry,
'Tis not a glasse can rob mee of my good fashion,
And Gentlemanly garbe. Follow, my deere.

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: I'le follow you. So, now y'are fast enough.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Help Armellina, help! I am fal'n i'th' cellar:
Bring a fresh Plantane leafe, I haue broke my shinne.

sp.speaker: ARM.
sp.l: Thus haue I caught m'a husband in a trap,
And in good earnest meane to marry him.
'Tis a tough Clowne and lusty: he works day & night;
And rich enough for me, that haue no portion
But my poore seruice. Well: hee's something foolish;
The better can I dominere, and rule him
At pleasure. That's the marke, and vtmost height
Wee women aime at. I am resolu'd; I'le haue him.

sp.speaker: LEL.
sp.l: IN, Armellina, lock vp Trincalo.

sp.speaker: AR.
sp.l: I will, sir.

sp.speaker: LEL.
sp.l: Cricca, for this thy counsell, if't succeed,
Feare not thy maisters anger: I'le preferre thee
And count thee as my Genius, or good fortune.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: It can not chuse but take. I know his humor;
And can at pleasure feather him with hopes,
Making him flye what pitch I wish, and stoope
When I shew fowle.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: But for the sute of cloathes?

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: I'le throw them o're your garden wall. Away.
Hast to Eugenio, and Sulpitia,
Acquaint them with the businesse.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: I go.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: THe hopefull issue of thy counsell, Cricca,
Brightens this eu'ning, and makes it more excell
The clearest day, then a gray morning doth
The blindest midnight: raising my amorous thoughts
To such a pitch of ioy, that riches, honour,
And other pleasures, to Sulpitia's loue,
Appeare like Mole-hils to the Moone.

sp.speaker: SVL.
sp.l: Lelio?

sp.speaker: LEL.
sp.l: O there's the voice that in one note containes
All cords of Musick: How gladly shee'l embrace
The newes I giue her, and the messenger!

sp.speaker: SVL.
sp.l: Soft, soft, y'are much mistaken: for in earnest,
I am angry Lelio; and with you.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: Sweetest, those flames
Rise from the sire of loue, and soone will quench
I'th' welcome newes I bring you.

sp.speaker: SVL.
sp.l: Stand still I charge you
By th'vertue of my lips; speake not a sillable
As you expect a kisse should close my choler.
For I must chide you.

sp.speaker: LEL.
sp.l: O my Sulpitia,
Were euery speech a Pistoll charg'd with death,
I'de stand them all in hope of that condition.

sp.speaker: SVL.
sp.l: First, sir, I heare, you teach Eugenio
Too graue a warinesse in your sisters loue,
And kill his honest forwardnesse of affection
With your farre-fet respects, suspitions, feares.
You haue your may-bee's; this is dangerous:
That course were better: for if so: and yet:
Who know's? th'euent is doubtfull: bee aduis'd:
'Tis a yong rashnesse: your father is your father:
Take leasure to consider. Thus y'haue considered
Poore Flauia almost to her graue. Fy Lelio,
Had this my smalnesse vndertooke the businesse,
And done no more in foure short winter daies
Then you in foure monthes, I'de haue vow'd my maydenhead
To th'liuing Tomb of a sad Nunnery.
Which for your sake I loath.

sp.speaker: LEL.
sp.l: Sweete by your fauour

sp.speaker: SVL.
sp.l: Peace! peace! Now y'are so wise as if y'had eaten
Nothing but braines, and marrow of Machiauell.
You tip your speeches with Italian Motti,
Spanish Refranes, and English Quoth Hee's. Beleeue mee
There's not a Prouerbe salt's your tongue, but plantes
Whole colonies of white haires. O what a businesse
These hands must haue when you haue married mee,
To pick out sentences that ouer-yeare you.

sp.speaker: LEL.
sp.l: Giue mee but leaue.

sp.speaker: SVL.
sp.l: Haue I a lip? and you
Made Sonnets on't? 'tis your fault, for otherwise,
Your sister and Eugenio had beene sure
Long time e're this.

sp.speaker: LEL.
sp.l: But—

sp.speaker: SVL.
sp.l: Stay, your Qu's not come yet.
I hate as perfectly this gray-greene of yours,
As old Antonio's greene-gray. Fy! Wise louers,
Are most absurd. Were not I full resolu'd,
I should beginne to coole mine owne affection.
For shame consider well your sister's temper.
Her melancholy may much hurt her. Respect her,
Or spight of mine owne loue, I'le make you stay
Six monthes, before you marry mee. Lelio whispers.

sp.speaker: SVL.
sp.l: This your so happy newes? return'd? and safe?
Antonio yet aliue? Lelio whispers.

sp.speaker: SVL.
sp.l: And then?

sp.speaker: SVL.
sp.l: Well. All your businesse must bee compassed
With winding plots, and cunning stratagems.
Look to't: For if we be not married e're next morning,
By the great loue that's hid in this small compasse,
Flauia and my selfe will steale you both away
To your eternall shame and foule discredit.

sp.speaker: LEL.
sp.l: How pretily this louely littlenesse,
In one breath plead's her owne cause, and my sister's;
Chides mee, and loues. This is that pleasing temper
I more admire, then a continued sweetnesse
That ouer-satisfie's: 'Tis salt I loue; not sugar.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: HOw? not a single share of this great prize,
That haue deseru'd the whole? was't not my plot,
And paines, and you meere instruments and porters?
Shall I haue nothing?

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: No, not a siluer spoone.

sp.speaker: FVR.
sp.l: Nor couer of a Trencher-salt.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.l: Nor Table-napkin?

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Friends; we haue kept an honest trust and faith
'Long time amongst vs Breake not that sacred league,
By raising ciuill theft, turne not your furie
'Gainst your owne bowels. Rob your carefull Maister!
Are you not asham'd?

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: 'Tis our profession,
As your's Astrologie. And in th'daies of old,
Good morrow Theefe, as welcome was receiu'd,
As now your Worship. 'Tis your owne instruction.

sp.speaker: FVR.
sp.l: The Spartans held it lawfull, and th'Arabians,
So grew Arabia, Happy: Sparta, Valiant.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.l: The world's a Theater of Theft: great Riuers
Rob smaller Brookes; and them the Ocean.

sp.speaker: AL.
sp.l: Haue not I wean'd you vp from peti-larceny,
Dangerous and poore? and nurst you to full strength
Of safe and gainefull theft? By rules of Art
And principles of cheating, made you as free
From taking, as you went inuisible?
And do yee thus requite mee? this the reward
For all my watchfull care?

sp.speaker: RO.
sp.l: We are your schollers,
Made by your helpe, and our owne aptnesse, able
To instruct others. 'Tis the Trade wee liue by.
You that are seruant to Diuine Astrologie,
Do something worth her liuery. Cast Figures,
Make Almanackes for all Meridians.

sp.speaker: FVR.
sp.l: Sell Perspicils, and Instruments of hearing,
Turne Clownes to Gentlemen, Buzzards to Falcons,
Cur-dogs to Grey-hounds, Kitchin-maids to Ladies.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.l: Discouer more new Stars, and vnknowne Planets:
Vent them by dozens, stile them by the names
Of men that buy such ware. Take lawfull courses,
Rather then beg.

sp.speaker: AL.
sp.l: Not keep your honest promise?

sp.speaker: FVR.
sp.l: Beleeue none, credit none: for in this Citie
No dwellers are, but Cheaters, and Cheateez.

sp.speaker: AL.
sp.l: You promist mee the greatest share.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Our promise!
If honest men by Obligations,
And instruments of Law, are hardly constrain'd
T'obserue their word; Can wee, that make profession
Of lawlesse courses, do't?

sp.speaker: AL.
sp.l: Amongst our selues.
Faulcons that tyrannize o're weaker fowle,
Hold peace with their owne feathers.

sp.speaker: HA.
sp.l: But when they counter
Vpon one quarrey, breake that league as wee do.

sp.speaker: AL.
sp.l: At least restoreth' ten pound in gold I lent you.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: 'Twas lent in an ill Second, worser Third,
And lucklesse Fourth: 'tis lost, Albumazar.

sp.speaker: FVR.
sp.l: Saturne was in Ascension. Mercury
Was then Combust when you deliuered it.
'Twill neuer be restor'd.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Hali, Abenezra,
Hiarcha, Brachman, Budda Babylonicus,
And all the Chaldes and the Cabalists,
Affirme that sad Aspect threat's losse of debts.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.l: Frame by your Azimut and Almicantarat,
An engine like a Mace, whose qualitie
Of strange retractiue vertue may recall
Desperate debts, and with that vndoe Sergeants.

sp.speaker: ALB.
sp.l: Was euer man thus baited by's owne whelps?
Giue mee a slender portion for a stock
To beginne Trade againe.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: 'Tis an ill course
And full of feares. This treasure hath inrich't vs,
And giuen vs meanes to purchase, and liue quiet
Of th'fruite of dangers past. When I vs'd robbing,
All blocks before me look't like Constables,
And posts appear'd in shape of Gallowses.
Therefore good Tutor take your pupils counsell:
'Tis better beg then steale: Liue in poore clothes,
Then hang in Sattin.

sp.speaker: AL.
sp.l: Villaines, I'le be reueng'd,
And reueale all the businesse to a Iustice.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Do, if thou long'st to see thy owne Anatomie.

sp.speaker: AL.
sp.l: This treachery perswade's mee to turne honest.

sp.speaker: FVR.
sp.l: Search your Natiuitie: see if the Fortunates
And Luminaries bee in a good Aspect.
And thank vs for thy life. Had wee done well,
We had cut thy throat e're this.

sp.speaker: AL.
sp.l: Albumazar,
Trust not these Rogues; hence and reuenge.

sp.speaker: RON.
sp.l: Fellowes away, here's company. Let's hence. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: NOw Cricca, mask thy countenance in ioy,
Speak welcome language of good newes, and moue
Thy Maister, whose desires are credulous,
To beleeue what thou giu'st him. If thy designe
Land at the Hauen 'tis bound for; then Lelio,
Eugenio, and their Mistresses, are oblig'd
By oath, t'assure a state of forty pounds
Vpon thee for thy life.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: I long to know
How my good Farmer speeds; how Trincalo
Hath bene receiu'd by Lelio.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Where shall I find him?
What wee most seeke, still flies vs; what's auoided,
Followes, or meetes vs full. I am embost
With trotting all the streetes to finde Pandolfo,
And blesse him with good newes.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: This hast of Cricca
Abodes some good; doubtlesse my Trincalo,
Receiued for Antonio, hath giuen me Flauia.
Cricca?

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Neither in Pauls, at home, nor in th'Exchange?
Nor where he vses to converse? hee's lost:
And must be cried.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Turne hither, Cricca: Cricca,
See'st me not?

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Sir, the newes, and hast to tell it,
Had almost blinded me. 'Tis so fortunate,
I dare not powre it all at once vpon you,
Least you should faint and swound away with ioy.
Your transform'd Trincalo-

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: What newes of him?

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Entred as owner in Antonio's house-

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: On.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Is acknowledg'd by his daughter Flauia,
And Lelio, for their father.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Quickly good Cricca!

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: And hath sent me in hast to bid you-

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Come with your sonne Eugenio.-

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: And then?

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: That he may be a witnesse of your marriage.
But sir, I see no signes of so large gladnesse
As I expected, and this newes deseru'd.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: 'Tis here, 'tis here, within. All outward symtomes
And characters of ioy, are poore expressions
Of my great inward happinesse: my heart's full,
And cannot vent the passions. Run Cricca, run,
Run, as thou lou'st me, call Eugenio,
And worke him to my purpose thou canst do it.
Haste, call him instantly.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: I flye sir.

sp.speaker: PANDOLFO.
sp.l: HOw shall I recompence this Astrologer?
This great Albumazar? through whose learned hands,
Fortune hath powr'd th'effect of my best wishes,
And crown'd my hopes. Giue him this chaine? alas!
'Tis a poore thankes, short by a thousand linkes
Of his large merit. No, he must liue with me,
And my sweet Flauia, at his ease and pleasure,
Wanting for nothing. And this very night
I'le get a boy, and he erect a figure
To calculate his fortunes. So there's Trincalo
Antoniated, or Antonio Intrinculate.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: SIgnior Pandolfo! welcome.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: Your seruant sir.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Well met Antonio, my praiers and wishes
Haue waited on you euer.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Thanks, deerest friend.
To speake my dangers past, were to discourse
Of dead men at a feast. Such sad relations
Become not marriages. Sir, I am here
Return'd to doe you seruice: where's your sonne?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Hee'l wait vpon you presently.

sp.speaker: EV.
sp.l: Signior Antonio!
Happily welcome.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Thankes Eugenio.
How thinke you gentlemen? were it amisse
To call downe Flauia and Sulpitia,
That what we do, may with a full consent
Be entertain'd by all?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: 'Tis well remembred.
Eugenio, call your sister.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Lelio, call my daughter.

sp.speaker: PA.
sp.l: WIsely consider'd Trincalo: 'tis a faire prologue
To th' Comoedy ensuing. Now I confesse
Albumazar had equall power to change,
And mend thy vnderstanding with thy body.
Let me embrace and hugge thee for this seruice.
'Tis a braue on-set: ah my sweet Trincalo!

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: How like you the beginning?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: 'Tis o'th further side
All expectation.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Was't not right? and spoken
Like old Antonio?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: 'Tis most admirable:
Wer't he himselfe that spake, he could not better't.
And for thy sake, I wish Antonio's shape
May ever be thy house, and's wit thy Inne-mate.
But wheres my plate, and cloath of siluer?

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Safe.

sp.speaker: PA.
sp.l: They come: keep state, keep state, or als discouer'd.

div.head: ACT. 5. SCEN. 6.
div.stage: ANTO. PAND. EVG. LEL. FLA. SVLP.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: EVgenio, Flauia, Lelio, and Sulpitia;
Marriages once confirm'd, and consummate,
Admit of no repentance. Therefore 'tis fitting
All parties with full freedome speake their pleasure,
Before it be too late.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Good! excellent!

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: Speake boldly therefore: do you willingly
Giue full authoritie, that what I decree
Touching these businesses, you'l all performe?

sp.speaker: EVG.
sp.l: I rest at your dispose: what you determine,
With my best power I ratifie; and Sulpitia,
I dare be bold to promise, sayes no lesse.

sp.speaker: SVL.
sp.l: What e're my father, brother, and your selfe
Shall thinke conuenient pleaseth me.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: In this,
As in all other seruice, I commit my selfe
To your commands; and so I hope, my sister.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: With all obedience: sir dispose of me
As of a child, that iudgeth nothing good
But what you shall approue.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: And you Pandolfo?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: I most of all. And, for I know the mindes
Of youth are apt to promise, and as prone
To repent after; 'tis my advice they sweare
T'obserue, without exception, your decree.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: SVL.
sp.l: Content

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: By all the powers that heare
Oathes, and raine vengeance vpon broken faith,
I promise to confirme and ratifie
Your sentence.

sp.speaker: LE.
sp.l: Sir, I sweare no lesse.

sp.speaker: EV.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: The selfe-same oath binds me.

sp.speaker: SVL.
sp.l: And me the same.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Now deare Antonio, all our expectation
Hangs at your mouth: None of vs can appeale
From you to higher Courts.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: First for preparatiue,
Or slight Praeludium to the greater matches;
I must intreate you that my Armellina
Be match't with Trincalo. Two hundred crownes
I giue her for her portion.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: 'Tis done. Some reliques
Of his old Clownery, and dregges o'th Countrey,
Dwell in him still: how carefull he prouides
For himselfe first! Content. And more, I grant him
A lease of twenty pounds a yeare.

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: I thanke you.
Gentlemen, since I feele my selfe much broken
With age, and my late miseries, and too cold
To entertaine new heate; I freely yeeld
Sulpitia, whom I lou'd, to my sonne Lelio.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: How cunningly the Farmer hath provided
T'obserue the semblance of Antonio's person,
And keepe himselfe still free for Armellina!

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Signior Pandolfo, y'are wise, and vnderstand
How ill hot appetites of vnbridled youth
Become gray haires. How graue and honourable
Wer't for your age to be inamored
With the faire shape of vertue, and the glory
Of your fore-fathers! Then would you blush to thinke
How by this dotage, and vnequall loue,
You staine their honour, and your owne. Awake,
Banish those wild affections; and by my example
Turne t'your reposed selfe.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: To what purpose, pray yo
Serues this long proaeme? on to th'sentence.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Sir,
Conformitie of yeares, likenesse of manners,
Are Gordian knots that bind vp matrimony.
Now betwixt seuenty Winters, and sixteene,
There's no proportion, nor least hope of loue.
Fye, that a gentleman of your discretion,
Crown'd with such reputation in your youth,
Should in your Westerne dayes, loose th'good opinion
Of all your friends; and run to th'open danger
Of closing the weake remnant of your dayes
With discontentment vnrecouerable.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Wrack me no more: pray you let's heare the sentence.
Note how the Asse would fright me, and indeere
His seruice; intimating, that his power
May ouer-throw my hopes. Proceed to th'sentence.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: These things consider'd, I bestow my daughter
Vpon your sonne Eugenio; whose constant loue
With his so modest carriage, hath deseru'd her.
And, that you freeze not for a bed-fellow,
I marry you with Patience.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Trecherous villaine!
Accursed Trincalo! Ile— But this no place,
Hee's too well back't. But shortly when the date
Of his Antonioship's expir'd, revenge
Shall sweeten this disgrace.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: Signior Pandolfo,
When you recouer your selfe, lost desperately
In disproportion'd dotage, then you'l thanke me
For this great fauour: be not obstinate:
Disquiet not your selfe.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: I thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: PANDOLFO.
sp.l: ANd that you freeze not for a bed-fellow,
I marry you with Patience. Traiterous villaine!
Is't not enough to wrong me, and betray me,
But 't must be done with scoffes? accursed Trincalo!
And me most miserable! that when I thought
T'embrace yong Flauia, see her before my face
Bestow'd vpon my sonne! my sonne my rivall!
This is Eugenio's plot, and his friend Lelio's;
Who, with my seruant Cricca, haue conspir'd,
And suborn'd Trincalo to betray his master.
Why doe I rage 'gainst any but my selfe,
That haue committed such a serious businesse
To th'hands of a base clowne, and ignorant?
I see mine error, but no meanes to helpe it.
Onely the sweetnesse of reuenge is left me,
Which I must execute: th'houres of's gentry
Are now cleane spent. I'le home, and there attend him.

sp.speaker: TRINCALO
sp.p: WElcome old trusty Trincalo, good Farmer welcome! giue me thy hand, wee must not part hereafter. Fye, what a trouble 'tis to be out of a mans selfe! If gentlemen haue no pleasure but what I felt to day; a teame of horses shall not dragge me out of my profession. There's nothing amongst them but borrowing, compounding for halfe their debts, and haue their purse cut for the rest, cosned by whores, frighted with husbands, wash't in wet hogges-heads, cheated of their clothes, and falling in cellars for conclusion.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: O Pretious peece of villany! are you vnchang'd?
How confident the rogue dares walke the streetes!

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.p: And then such quarrelling: neuer a sute I wore to day, but hath been soundly basted. Onely this faithfull Countrey case scap't fist-free; and bee it spoken in a good houre, was neuer beaten yet since it came from fulling!

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Tiff. toff. Base treacherous villaine! toff. toff. toff.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Is this the recompence of my dayes worke?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: You marry me to patience? there's patience.
And that you freeze not, there's warme patience,
Shee's a good bed-fellow; haue patience.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: You'l beat me out on't sir: how haue I wrong'd you?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: So, as deserues th'expression of my fury
With th'cruelst tortures I can execute.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: You kill me sir.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Haue patience.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Pray you sir!

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Seeke not by humble penitence t'appease me.
Nothing can satisfie.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Fare-well humilitie.
Now am I beaten sober. (takes away Pandolfo's staffe)
Shall age and weaknesse master my youth and strength?
Now speake your pleasure: what's my fault?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Dar'st deny
Thy owne act done before so many witnesses?
Suborn'd by others, and betray my confidence
With such a stony impudence?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: I haue bin faithfull
In all you trusted me.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: To them; not me.
O what a Proaeme stuft with graue advice,
And learned counsaile, you could showre vpon me
Before the thunder of your deadly sentence!
And giue away my Mistresse with a scoffe!

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: I giue your Mistresse?

sp.speaker: PA.
sp.l: Did'st not thou decree
Contrary t'our compact, against my marriage?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Why when was I your iudge?

sp.speaker: PA.
sp.l: Iust now, here.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: See your error!
Then was I fast lock't in Antonio's Cellar:
Where making vertue of necessitie,
I drunke starke drunke; and waking, found my selfe
Cloth'd in this Farmers sute, as in the morning.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Did'st not thou sweare t'enter Antonio's house,
And giue me Flauia for my wife? and after,
Before my owne face, gau'st her to my sonne?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: PA.
sp.l: Canst thou deny't?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha! Whilst Trincalo laughes, and fals the staffe, Pandolfo recouers it, and beates him.
Haue you got mistresse Patience? ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Is not this true?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: PA.
sp.l: Answere me.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha wan!

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Was't not thus?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: I answere. First, I neuer was transform'd,
But gul'd, as you were, by th'Astrologer
And those that cal'd m'Antonio. To proue this true,
The gentleman you spoke with, was Antonio,
The right Antonio, safely return'd from Barbarie.

sp.speaker: PA.
sp.l: Oi me! what's this?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Truth it selfe.

sp.speaker: PA.
sp.l: Was't not thou
That gau'st the sentence?

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Beleeue me no such matter:
I nere was gentleman, nor otherwise
Then what I am, vnlesse 'twere when I was drunke.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: How haue I beene deceiu'd! good Trincalo
Pardon mee. I haue wrong'd thee.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Pardon you?
When you haue beaten mee to paste, good Trincalo
Pardon mee?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: I am sorry for't; excuse mee.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: I am sory I must excuse you. But I pardon you.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Now tell mee where's the plate and cloath of siluer,
The gold and iewels that th'Astrologer
Committed to thy keeping?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: What Plate, what iewels?
Hee gaue mee none. But when he went to change mee,
After a thousand circles and ceremonies,
Hee bindes mee fast vpon a forme, and blindes mee
With a thick Table-napkin. Not long after
Vnbinds my head and feete, and giues mee light:
And then I plainely saw, that I saw nothing;
The Parler was cleane swep't of all was in't.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Ojh me? ojh me!

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: What ailes you? Sir, what ailes you?

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: I am vndone, I haue lost my Loue, my plate,
My whole estate, and with the rest my selfe.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Loose not your patience too. Leaue this lamenting,
And lay the Towne; you may recouer it.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: 'Tis to small purpose. In, and hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: WHere shall I find my Maister to content him
With welcome newes? Hee's here; newes! newes!
Newes of good fortune, ioy and happinesse!

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Cricca, my sadnesse is vncapable
Of better tidings: I am vndone most miserable!

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Offend not your good luck, y'are now more fortunate
Then when you rose this morning: Bee merry, sir,
Cheare vp your selfe, y'haue what you wisht, feare nothing.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: May bee Antonio newly repents himselfe,
With purpose to restore my Flauia.
Cricca, what is't? where's all this happinesse?

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Lock't in Antonio's Closet.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: All alone?
Sure that's my Flauia. Is not Eugenio
Suffred to enter?

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Antonio keepes the key:
No creature enter's but himselfe. Al's safe
And shall be so restor'd.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: O my sweet Cricca!

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: And they that wrong'd you, most extremely sory,
Ready to yeeld you any satisfaction.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Is't possible they should so soone repent them?
That iniur'd mee so lately? tell mee the manner
That caus'd them see their errour.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: I'le tell you, sir.
Being iust now at old Antonio's house,
One thunder's at th'back dore, enters, and presses
To speake in priuate with yong Lelio;
Was instantly admitted: And thinke you who?
'Twas your Astrologer Albumazar.
When hee had spoke a while; Lelio and Antonio
In hast command 'mee fetch a Constable.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: How can this Story touch my happinesse?

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: I vp and downe throw slimie Ale-houses,
Clowdie Tobacco-shops, and vapouring Tauernes:
My mouth full of enquiry; At last found one.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: What of all this? is't possible a Constable
Concernes my good?

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: And following my directions,
Went to a Tippling-house, where wee tooke drinking
Three hansome fellowes with a great Chest; Attach't them,
And brought all to Antonio.

sp.speaker: PAN.
sp.l: Well, what then?

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: These were th'Astrologers intelligences.
That rob'd you through th'South window.

sp.speaker: PA.
sp.l: I thought th'hadst spoken
Of Flauia's restoring.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: I meane your plate
And treasure; pray you, sir, is't not great happinesse
To re-obtaine three thousand pounds in valew,
Desperately lost? and you still dote and dreame
Of Flauia, who by your owne consent
And oath is promis'd to your sonne Eugeni?

sp.speaker: PA,
sp.l: Forward.

sp.speaker: CR.
sp.l: Within this Chest Antonio found your Plate,
Gold, Iewels, cloath of siluer, nothing perish't,
But all safe lock't till you acknowledge it.
And since Albumazar of his owne accord
Freely confest, and safe restor'd your treasure:
Since 'tis a day of Iubile and marriage;
Antonio would entreate you to release
And pardon the Astrologer: Thanking your fortune
That hath restor'd you to your wealth, and selfe.
Both which were lost i'th' foolish loue of Flauia.

sp.speaker: PA.
sp.l: Reason hath clear'd my sight, and drawne the vaile
Of dotage that so dark't my vnderstanding.
I clearely see the slau'ry of affections;
And how vnsutable my declining yeares
Are for the dawning youth of Flauia.
Let the best ioies of Hymen compasse her,
And her yong husband, my Eugenio,
With full content. And since Albumazar
By accident, caus'd all this happinesse;
I freely pardon him, and his companions:
And hast t'assist the marriages and feasts.

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Why now you shew your selfe a worthy Gentleman.

sp.speaker: TRIN.
sp.l: CRicca I ouer-heard your newes: all parts are pleas'd
Except my selfe. Is there no newes for Trincalo?

sp.speaker: CRIC.
sp.l: Know'st it not? In, and see: Antonio
Hath giu'n thee Armellina with a portion,
Two hundreth Crownes: and old Pandolfo bound
By oath t'assure thee twenty pounds a yeare,
For three liues.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: Haj!

sp.speaker: CRI.
sp.l: Come in.

sp.speaker: TR.
sp.l: I'le follow.
TWo hundred Crownes? and twentie pound a yeare
For three good liues? Cargo! Hai Trincalo!
My wife's extreamely busie, dressing the supper
For these great marriages; and I not idle,
So that I cannot entertaine you here
As I would else-where. But if you come to Totnam
Some foure dayes hence, and aske for Trincalo
At th'signe o'th Hogshead; I'le morgage all my liues
To bid you welcome. You that loue Trincalo,
And meane to meete, clappe hands and mak't a bargaine.
